member.name: T:RT.Util.Collections.AutoDictionary`2
member.summary: Implements a dictionary with a slightly different indexer, namely one that pretends every key has been pre-initialized using an initializer function. See Remarks.
member.remarks: Only the indexer behaviour is changed; in every other way this behaves just like a standard, non-prepopulated dictionary. Moreover, the implementation is such that the new behaviour is only effective when used directly through the class; accessing the indexer through the IDictionary interface or the Dictionary base class will currently behave the same as it would for a standard dictionary.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Collections.AutoList`1
member.summary: Encapsulates a list which dynamically grows as items are written to non-existent indexes. Any gaps are populated with default values. The behaviour of this list's indexed getter and setter is indistinguishable from that of an infinitely long list pre-populated by invoking the initializer function (assuming it is side-effect free). See Remarks.

remarks.para: Only the indexer behaviour is changed; in every other way this behaves just like a standard, non-infinite list. Moreover, the implementation is such that the new behaviour is only effective when used directly through the class; accessing the indexer through the IList interface or the List base class will currently behave the same as it would for a standard list.
Note that this is not a sparse list; accessing elements at a given index will grow the list to contain all of the items below the index too.

member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: A function which creates a value to be used for non-existent elements upon their creation. If null, default(T) is used instead.

member.summary: Constructor.

member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Collections.Bin128
member.summary: Encapsulates a binary value 128 bits long. See Remarks.
member.remarks: This type is significantly more memory-efficient compared to byte[16] when only one copy of the value needs to be stored. Specifically, the byte array uses four extra IntPtrs per instance, which, on a 64-bit platform, amounts to a three-fold RAM usage increase. It can also be compared for equality using just two integer comparisons in safe code.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Collections.Bin128.Zero
member.summary: Gets a 128-bit binary value consisting of all zeroes.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.Bin128.#ctor(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructor. Initializes this value to contain the same data as the specified byte array.
member.param: Byte array containing the data.
The offset at which the data begins. The length is fixed at 16 bytes.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.Bin128.op_Equality(RT.Util.Collections.Bin128,RT.Util.Collections.Bin128)
member.summary: Compares the two values and returns true iff they are equal.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.Bin128.op_Inequality(RT.Util.Collections.Bin128,RT.Util.Collections.Bin128)
member.summary: Compares the two values and returns true iff they are different.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.Bin128.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Compares an object to this value and returns true iff it's a Bin128 value that's equal.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.Bin128.GetHashCode
member.summary: Gets the hash code for this value.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.Bin128.ToArray
member.summary: Returns the binary value as a byte array. This method is not very efficient.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.Bin128.ToString
member.summary: Converts the binary value to a hexadecimal string representation.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.Bin128.Write(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Writes the value to the specified stream as 16 bytes.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.Bin128.Write(System.IO.BinaryWriter)
member.summary: Writes the value to the specified binary writer as 16 bytes.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.Bin128.Read(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Reads a 128-bit binary value from the specified stream.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.Bin128.Read(System.IO.BinaryReader)
member.summary: Reads a 128-bit binary value from the specified binary reader.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1
member.summary: Implements a list whose items are always stored in a sorted order. Multiple equal items are allowed, and will always be added to the end of a run of equal items. Insertion, and removal are O(N); lookups are O(log N); access by index is supported.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.#ctor
member.summary: Creates an empty using a default comparer for the item type.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates an empty of the specified capacity and using a default comparer for the item type.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IComparer{`0})
member.summary: Creates an empty using the specified item comparer.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Collections.Generic.IComparer{`0})
member.summary: Creates an empty of the specified capacity and using the specified item comparer.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.AddRange(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: Adds all of the specified items into the list. The resulting list will contain all the items in the same order as a stable sort would have produced. NOTE: the current implementation is O(N log N) if the collection is empty, or O(N*M) otherwise, where N = items currently in the collection and M = items to be added. The latter can be improved.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.IndexOf(`0)
member.summary: Returns the index of the FIRST item equal to the specified item, or -1 if the item is not found. The operation is O(log N).

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.LastIndexOf(`0)
member.summary: Returns the index of the LAST item equal to the specified item, or -1 if the item is not found. The operation is O(log N).

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.Insert(System.Int32,`0)
member.summary: Not supported in this class, will always throw an exception.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.RemoveAt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the item at the specified index.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.Add(`0)
member.summary: Adds the specified item to the list. The item is added at the appropriate location to keep the list sorted. If multiple equal items are stored, this method is guaranteed to add an item at the end of the equal items run. This method is O(N).

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.Clear
member.summary: Removes all items from the list.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.Contains(`0)
member.summary: Returns true if the list contains the specified item. This operation is O(logN).

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.CopyTo(`0[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Copies all items of this collection into the specified array, starting at the specified index, in the sorted order.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.Remove(`0)
member.summary: Removes the FIRST occurrence of the specified item from the list. Returns true if the item was removed, or false if it wasn't found.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.RemoveLast(`0)
member.summary: Removes the LAST occurrence of the specified item from the list. Returns true if the item was removed, or false if it wasn't found.

member.summary: Gets an enumerator which enumerates all items of this collection in sorted order.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.System#Collections#IEnumerable#GetEnumerator
member.summary: Gets an enumerator which enumerates all items of this collection in sorted order.

member.summary: Gets the number of items stored in this collection.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Collections.ListSorted`1.IsReadOnly
member.summary: Returns false.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Collections.RecentlyUsedCache`2
member.summary: Implements a key-value store which remembers which keys were used more recently than others, and automatically trims the older entries once a threshold is reached. Lookups are O(1) and are comparable in speed to a Dictionary`2. So are additions, except when a trim is triggered.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.RecentlyUsedCache`2.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: Whenever the cache has this many entries, a trim will be triggered.
The minimum number of most recently used entries to remain in the cache after trimming. The actual number of entries will be somewhere between and 2 * .

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.RecentlyUsedCache`2.Retrieve(`0,`1@)
member.summary: Gets a value associated with the specified key, and records it as recently used.
member.param: The key to retrieve.
Receives the value in case of successful lookup, or default(TValue) if the specified key is not currently stored.
member.returns: True if the key was found, false otherwise.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Collections.RecentlyUsedCache`2.Store(`0,`1)

member.name: T:RT.Util.CommandLine.CommandLineParser
member.summary: Implements a command-line parser that can turn the commands and options specified by the user on the command line into a strongly-typed instance of a specific class. See remarks for more details.

remarks.para: The following conditions must be met by the class wishing to receive the options and parameters:

item.description: It must be a reference type (a class) and it must have a parameterless constructor.

description.para: Every field in the class must have one of the following custom attributes:

item.description: (allowed for all supported types except bool) — specifies that the field is a positional parameter; the user specifies this as a single parameter without any extra syntax.
(allowed for all supported types except abstract classes) — specifies that the field is a parameter invoked by an option, e.g. -x. (This does not imply that the parameter is necessarily optional.)
(allowed for enum types only) — specifies that the field is a parameter that can be invoked by one of several options, which are specified on the enum values in the enum type.
— specifies that shall completely ignore the field.

description.para: Each field may optionally have any of the following custom attributes:

item.description: (allowed for all supported types except bool) — specifies that the parameter must be specified by the user. For a string[] field, it means that at least one value must be specified.
— specifies that the option or command does not appear in the help screen generated by CommandLineParser.

description.para: Each field in the class must be of one of the following types:

item.description: string, any integer type, float, double, or any nullable version of these. The field can be positional () or not ().
string[]. The field can be positional () or not (), but if it is positional, it must be the last field in the class.
bool. The field must have an and cannot be positional or mandatory.
An abstract class with the . The field must be the last field in the class and must be marked positional (). The abstract class must have at least two derived classes, each with a .

description.para: Any enum type. There are three ways that enum types can be used. To explain these, the following enum type declaraction is used as an example:
— The user can specify a single parameter (e.g. plain or xml) to select an enum value. Every value in the enum type must have a to specify the name by which that enum value is selected:

item.description: — The user can select an enum value by specifying an option followed by a parameter that identifies the enum value (e.g. -x plain or -x xml). As above, every value in the enum type must have a to specify the name by which that enum value is selected.

description.para: — The user can select an enum value by specifying just an option (e.g. -p or -x). Every value in the enum type must have an to specify the option by which that enum value is selected:
A parameter on the attribute determines whether the user is allowed to specify only one enum value or multiple (which will be combined using bitwise or).

item.description: If the field is optional, the enum value that corresponds to the field’s initial (default) value may omit the or .

description.para: Every field must have documentation or be explicitly marked with , except for fields that use or . For every field whose type is an enum type, the values in the enum type must also have documentation or , except for the enum value that corresponds to the field’s default value if the field is not mandatory.
Documentation is provided in one of the following ways:

item.description: Monolingual, translation-agnostic (unlocalisable) applications use the to specify documentation directly.

description.para: Translatable applications must declare methods with the following signature:

The first parameter must be of the same type as the object passed in for the applicationTr parameter of . The name of the method is the name of the field or enum value followed by Doc. The return value is the translated string.

item.description: and can be used together. However, a positional field can only be made mandatory if all the positional fields preceding it are also mandatory.

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandLine.CommandLineParser.Colorize(RT.Util.RhoElement)
member.summary: Converts the specified parse tree into a console colored string according to CommandLineParser-specific rules. This method is used to convert documentation into colored text. See Remarks.
member.remarks: A number of named tags have a special meaning. Any tag named after a value of results in that color. Both spellings of gray/grey are supported. The {h}...{} named tag stands for the highlight color (white). {nowrap}...{} can be placed around text that must not be broken into multiple lines by the word wrapper. The tags {field}, {option}, {command} and {enum} are used to refer to the corresponding command line syntax element, and is highlighted the same way the documentation generator would highlight references to these entities.

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandLine.CommandLineParser.Colorize(RT.Util.EggsNode)
member.summary: Converts the specified parse tree into a console colored string using the rules described in . This method is used to convert documentation into colored text, as well as any documentation using the legacy .

member.name: M:RT.Util.Consoles.ConsoleColoredString.FromEggsNode(RT.Util.EggsNode)
member.summary: Constructs a from an EggsML parse tree.
member.param: The root node of the EggsML parse tree.
member.returns: The constructed from the EggsML parse tree.

remarks.para: The following EggsML tags map to the following console colors:

item.description: ~ = black, or dark gray if inside a * tag
/ = dark blue, or blue if inside a * tag
$ = dark green, or green if inside a * tag
& = dark cyan, or cyan if inside a * tag
_ = dark red, or red if inside a * tag
% = dark magenta, or magenta if inside a * tag
^ = dark yellow, or yellow if inside a * tag
= = dark gray (independent of * tag)

remarks.para: Text which is not inside any of the above color tags defaults to light gray, or white if inside a * tag.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Consoles.ConsoleUtil
member.summary: Console-related utility functions.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Consoles.ConsoleUtil.StdOutState
member.summary: Determines the state of the standard output stream. The first call determines the state and caches it; subsequent calls return the cached value.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Consoles.ConsoleUtil.StdErrState
member.summary: Determines the state of the standard error stream. The first call determines the state and caches it; subsequent calls return the cached value.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Consoles.ConsoleUtil.WrapToWidth
member.summary: Returns the maximum line width that console applications should use to correctly word-wrap their output. If the output is redirected to a file, this will return an arbitrary but sensible value, otherwise the value reflects the width of the console buffer.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Consoles.ConsoleUtil.WriteParagraphs(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Outputs the specified message to the console window, treating newlines as paragraph breaks. All paragraphs are word-wrapped to fit in the console buffer, or to a sensible width if redirected to a file. Each paragraph is indented by the number of spaces at the start of the corresponding line.
member.param: The message to output.
Specifies a number of spaces by which the message is indented in all but the first line of each paragraph.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Consoles.ConsoleUtil.WriteParagraphs(RT.Util.EggsNode,System.Int32)
member.summary: Outputs the specified coloured message, marked up using EggsML, to the console window, treating newlines as paragraph breaks. All paragraphs are word-wrapped to fit in the console buffer, or to a sensible width if redirected to a file. Each paragraph is indented by the number of spaces at the start of the corresponding line.
member.param: The message to output.
Specifies a number of spaces by which the message is indented in all but the first line of each paragraph.
member.remarks: See for the colour syntax.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Consoles.ConsoleUtil.WriteParagraphs(RT.Util.Consoles.ConsoleColoredString,System.Int32)
member.summary: Outputs the specified message to the console window, treating newlines as paragraph breaks. All paragraphs are word-wrapped to fit in the console buffer, or to a sensible width if redirected to a file. Each paragraph is indented by the number of spaces at the start of the corresponding line.
member.param: The message to output.
Specifies a number of spaces by which the message is indented in all but the first line of each paragraph.

member.summary: Writes the specified to the console.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Consoles.ConsoleUtil.WriteLine(RT.Util.Consoles.ConsoleColoredString,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Writes the specified followed by a newline to the console.

member.summary: Writes the specified or current stack trace to the console in pretty colors.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Controls.DoubleBufferedPanel
member.summary: Provides a double-buffered drawing surface with an off-screen buffer. All painting is done into the buffer, which is then blitted onto the screen as required. Repainting of the off-screen buffer is only done on size changes or explicit calls to .

member.name: F:RT.Util.Controls.DoubleBufferedPanel.Buffer
member.summary: Holds the off-screen image. Initialised only when the first refresh occurs.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Controls.DoubleBufferedPanel.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Controls.DoubleBufferedPanel.Refresh
member.summary: Forces an update of the off-screen buffer, by invoking the event. Then forces a normal refresh of the underlying panel, which causes the off-screen buffer to be repainted over the whole panel.

member.name: E:RT.Util.Controls.DoubleBufferedPanel.PaintBuffer
member.summary: Occurs when the off-screen buffer needs to be painted.

member.name: E:RT.Util.Controls.DoubleBufferedPanel._previousPaintBuffer
member.summary: Is used for detecting that the paint buffer must be repainted due to the paint event handler changing.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Controls.DoubleBufferedPanel.RefreshOnResize
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the panel should automatically refresh its contents (i.e. call the PaintBuffer event) every time it is resized.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Controls.DoubleBufferedPanel.TabStop
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the user can give the focus to this control using the TAB key. This property’s value automatically changes every time Text changes; it is set to true if there is a link in the text, false otherwise. To achieve deviant behaviour, set TabStop immediately after setting Text.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Controls.HotkeyEdit
member.summary: This control enables the user to specify a hotkey combination by pressing it on the keyboard. For exmaple, if the user presses Ctrl + Alt + A while this control is focussed, the control would display "Ctrl+Alt+A". The combination can be read out by the program in a convenient format.

member.summary: Occurs when a link within the label is activated (via mouse click, Space or Enter).

member.summary: Occurs when a link within the label loses the keyboard focus.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Controls.LabelEx.Text
member.summary: Text displayed in the label. See remarks for EggsML supported. Setting this property also changes the value of the property depending on whether the text contains any links. To achieve deviant behaviour, set TabStop immediately after setting Text.

item.description: * = bold.
/ = italics.
_ = underline.
+ = marks a section of text as nowrap.
<XYZ>{ ... } = make the text enclosed in curlies a link. XYZ can be any string and will be passed in for the event.
<XYZ>= ... = = colour the text enclosed in equals sign in the colour designated by XYZ (e.g. “Red”).
[ ... ] = adds a bullet point to the beginning of a paragraph. (Enclose the entire paragraph without its trailing newline, otherwise behaviour is weird.)

member.name: T:RT.Util.CustomCallStack
member.summary: Provides static functionality to execute work on an unlimited call stack, which is not limited to 1 MB as the standard call stack is.

member.name: M:RT.Util.CustomCallStack.Run``1(RT.Util.WorkNode{``0})
member.summary: Runs the specified work on a custom call stack, which is not limited to 1 MB as the standard call stack is. See remarks for details.
member.typeparam: Type of result to compute.
member.param: Work to be executed.
member.returns: The result of the computation.

remarks.para: expects a delegate that is structured in such a way that it:

item.description: always knows at what state in the computation it is each time it is called;
returns a each time it requires some other value to be computed, and then expects that resulting value to come in through the parameter next time it is called;
returns a when it is done. At this point the delegate is not called again.
The delegate may return null to indicate the same as a containing a default(T) value.

remarks.para: CustomCallStack works as follows:

item.description: The first time the specified delegate is called, its parameter receives default(T).
If the value returned by the delegate is a , the work is done and the result is returned.

If the value returned is a , this is treated similarly to a method call. The old delegate is pushed on a stack and the new delegate is executed according to the same rules until it returns a . Once it does so, the original delegate is popped from the stack and then called with the result passed into its parameter.

remarks.para: There are deliberately no safeguards in this algorithm; it will allow you to grow the stack indefinitely and not generate an equivalent to the . This means that if your delegates always return a , they will consume memory rampantly and never finish.

member.typeparam: Type of result to compute.
member.remarks: This type is closed: Every value is either null or an instance of or . The value null is treated as being equivalent to a containing a default(T).

member.name: T:RT.Util.CuteML
member.summary: Implements a parser for the minimalist text mark-up language CuteML.

remarks.para: The “rules” of CuteML are, in summary:

item.description: A CuteML tag starts with [ and ends with ].
The character following the [ is the tag name. This can be any character except for <. For example, the following is legal CuteML: this is [*bold] text.

Optional attribute data may be inserted between the [ and the tag name enclosed in <...>. For example, the following is legal CuteML: this is [<red>:red] text. This attribute data may not contain the characters [, ] or <.
The special tags [(] and [)] can be used to insert an opening and closing literal square bracket, respectively.
The special tag [ ...] (i.e., the tag name is the space character) can be used to insert a matching literal square bracket. In other words, [ xyz] is equivalent to [(]xyz[)].

member.name: M:RT.Util.CuteML.ParseCuteML(System.String)
member.summary: Parses the specified CuteML input.
member.param: The CuteML text to parse.
member.returns: The resulting parse-tree.

item.description: Tags are parsed into instances of .
The top-level nodes are contained in an instance of whose property is set to null.
All the literal text is parsed into instances of . All continuous text is consolidated, so there are no two consecutive instances in any list of children.

member.exception: Invalid syntax was encountered. The exception object contains the string index at which the error was detected.
was null.

member.name: M:RT.Util.CuteML.EscapeCuteML(System.String)
member.summary: Escapes the input string such that it can be used in CuteML syntax. The result will have its [ and ] replaced with [(] and [)].

member.name: M:RT.Util.CuteML.WordWrap``1(RT.Util.CuteNode,``0,System.Int32,RT.Util.CuteML.CuteMeasure{``0},RT.Util.CuteML.CuteRender{``0},RT.Util.CuteML.CuteNextLine{``0},RT.Util.CuteML.CuteNextState{``0})
member.summary: Word-wraps a given piece of CuteML, assuming that it is linearly flowing text. Newline (\n) characters can be used to split the text into multiple paragraphs. The special [+...] tag marks text that may not be broken by wrapping (effectively turning all spaces into non-breaking spaces).
member.typeparam: The type of the text state that a tag can change, e.g. font or color.
member.param: The root node of the CuteML tree to word-wrap.
The initial text state.
The maximum width at which to word-wrap. This width can be measured in any unit, as long as uses the same unit.
A delegate that measures the width of any piece of text.
A delegate that is called whenever a piece of text is ready to be rendered.
A delegate that is called to advance to the next line.
A delegate that determines how each CuteML tag character modifies the state (font, color etc.).
member.returns: The maximum width of the text.

member.name: T:RT.Util.CuteML.CuteRender`1
member.summary: Provides a delegate for which renders a piece of text.
member.typeparam: The type of the text state, e.g. font or color.
member.param: The state (font, color, etc.) the string is in.
The string to render.
The measured width of the string.

member.name: T:RT.Util.CuteML.CuteMeasure`1
member.summary: Provides a delegate for which measures the width of a string.
member.typeparam: The type of the text state, e.g. font or color.
member.param: The state (font, color etc.) of the text.
The text whose width to measure.
member.returns: The width of the text in any arbitrary unit, as long as the “width” parameter in the call to is in the same unit.

member.name: T:RT.Util.CuteML.CuteNextLine`1
member.summary: Provides a delegate for which advances to the next line.
member.typeparam: The type of the text state, e.g. font or color.
member.param: The state (font, color etc.) of the text.
‘true’ if a new paragraph begins, ‘false’ if a word is being wrapped within a paragraph.
If is false, the indentation of the current paragraph as measured only by its leading spaces; otherwise, zero.
member.returns: The indentation for the next line. Use this to implement, for example, hanging indents.

member.name: T:RT.Util.CuteML.CuteNextState`1
member.summary: Provides a delegate for which determines how the text state (font, color etc.) changes for a given CuteML tag character. This delegate is called for all tags except for [+...], which is automatically processed to mean “nowrap”.
member.typeparam: The type of the text state, e.g. font or color.
member.param: The previous state (for the parent tag).
The CuteML tag character.
The contents of the tag attribute, which can be used to parameterize tags.
member.returns: The next state (return the old state for all tags that should not have a meaning) and an integer indicating the amount by which opening this tag has advanced the text position.

member.summary: Contains a node in the CuteML parse tree.

member.summary: Returns the CuteML parse tree as XML.

member.summary: Constructor.

member.summary: Gets the text of this node and/or sub-nodes concatenated into one string.

member.name: M:RT.Util.CuteNode.ToConsoleColoredStrings(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates a sequence of s from a CuteML parse tree by word-wrapping the output at a specified character width.
member.param: The number of characters at which to word-wrap the output.
The number of spaces to add to each line except the first of each paragraph, thus creating a hanging indentation.
member.returns: The sequence of s generated from the CuteML parse tree.

remarks.para: The following CuteML tags are processed:

item.description: [<color>:...] = use the specified console color, for example [<darkred>:...].
[*blah] = Brightens the current color, for example turning dark-red into red or light-gray into white.
[-blah] = Darkens the current color, for example turning red into dark-red or white into light-gray.

[+blah] = Suppresses word-wrapping within a certain stretch of text. In other words, the contents of a [+...] tag are treated as if they were a single word. Use this in preference to U+00A0 (no-break space) as it is more explicit and more future-compatible in case hyphenation is ever implemented here.

remarks.para: Text which is not inside a color tag defaults to light gray.

member.summary: Performs a GET request to the specified URL and with the specified query parameters.
member.param: The URL of the request. If the URL does not begin with http:// or https://, it is automatically prepended with .
Query parameters to add to the end of the URL in the usual ?k1=v1&k2=v2&... format. Null values are allowed and ignored.
member.returns: The response received from the server.

member.name: M:RT.Util.HClient.Post(System.String,System.Byte[],System.String)
member.summary: Performs a POST request with the body of the request specified as raw data.

The body of the request, as raw data.
The value of the Content-Type header.
member.returns: The response received from the server.

member.name: M:RT.Util.HClient.Post(System.String,RT.Util.HArg[])
member.summary: Performs a POST request with the body consisting of a series of key-value arguments.
member.param: The URL of the request. If the URL does not begin with http:// or https://, it is automatically prepended with .
The arguments to pass with the POST request. Null values are allowed and ignored.
member.returns: The response received from the server.
member.remarks: This method automatically calls either or depending on whether the provided arguments contain any file uploads or not.

member.name: M:RT.Util.HClient.PostUrlencoded(System.String,RT.Util.HArg[])
member.summary: Performs a POST request with the body consisting of a series of key-value arguments, encoded in the application/x-www-form-urlencoded format.
member.param: The URL of the request. If the URL does not begin with http:// or https://, it is automatically prepended with .
The arguments to pass with the POST request. Null values are allowed and ignored.
member.returns: The response received from the server.
member.remarks: Choose this format for requests that need to be small and do not contain any file uploads.

member.name: M:RT.Util.HClient.PostFormdata(System.String,RT.Util.HArg[])
member.summary: Performs a POST request with the body consisting of a series of key-value arguments, encoded in the multipart/form-data format.

The arguments to pass with the POST request. Null values are allowed and ignored.
member.returns: The response received from the server.
member.remarks: Choose this format for requests that need to contain file uploads.

member.summary: Releases a reference to this array. When there are none left, the array is unpinned and can get garbage-collected.

member.summary: X axis grows towards the right and Y axis grows downwards (normal computer screen coordinate direction)

member.name: T:RT.Util.Drawing.TextAnchor
member.summary: Specifies text alignment for .

summary.para: Wraps a to provide a hopefully more convenient interface. The major bits of functionality are:

item.description: all coordinates in doubles or structs;
support for the Y axis growing upwards;
functions targeted at drawing a 2d world onto a viewport of a specified size.
Rectangular area that will be the final destination of the drawing.
The region, defined in terms of the world coordinates, that is viewable on the screen.
Coordinates of the underlying "world" being represented.
Coordinates on the screen, can be used to directly draw on the underlying Graphics.
World X, Y, Width, Height, respectively
Screen X, Y, Width, Height, respectively

member.name: F:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.Graphics
member.summary: The underlying Graphics. All the actual drawing is done onto this instance.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.CoordinateAxesDirection
member.summary: Selects a coordinate axes mode.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.ScreenSize
member.summary: Stores the screen size. "Screen" here refers to the final surface that this Canvas is destined for. The screen size is used for "set viewport" methods which do not take a screen location: they assume the relevant screen edge is meant instead.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.DefaultFont
member.summary: The font to be used by text drawing functions if no font is specified.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.#ctor
member.summary: Creates an instance without initializing any of the required fields.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.#ctor(System.Drawing.Graphics)
member.summary: Creates an instance using the specified Graphics as the underlying drawing surface.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.#ctor(System.Drawing.Graphics,System.Drawing.Size)
member.summary: Creates an instance using the specified graphics and screenSize. See for more info.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.ResetViewport
member.summary: Resets the scaling and offset so that world coordinates correspond to screen pixels. Maintains the offsets so that all visible pixels have positive coordinates and one of the corners is 0,0.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.SetViewport(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Sets the viewport so that the specified world coordinate is in the centre of the viewable screen, using the specified scaling factor.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.SetViewport(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets the scaling and offset so that the world coordinate "leftWX" corresponds to the leftmost coordinate on the screen, world "topWY" to the topmost screen coordinate, etc. If "maintainAspect" is "true", ensures that X and Y scaling is the same, by making one of the axes show more than implied by the arguments passed in.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.MoveViewport(System.Single,System.Single,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Adjusts the offsets so that the world coordinate wx,wy is at the screen coordinate sx,sy. Does not modify the scaling.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.SX(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts world X coordinate into screen X. Screen X is zero at the leftmost pixel and Screen.Width at the rightmost pixel.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.SY(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts world Y coordinate into screen Y. Screen Y is zero at the topmost pixel and Screen.Height at the bottommost pixel.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.SW(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts world width into screen width. Screen width is measured in pixels.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.SH(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts world height into screen height. Screen height is measured in pixels.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.sa(System.Double)
member.summary: For internal use only. Converts world angle into screen angle as understood by GDI routines.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.sTop(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: For internal use only. Given two world coordinates, one known to be smaller than the other one, returns the one that would be higher on the screen, converted to screen coordinates.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.WX(System.Single)
member.summary: Converts screen X coordinate into world X. Screen X is zero at the leftmost pixel and Screen.Width at the rightmost pixel.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.WY(System.Single)
member.summary: Converts screen Y coordinate into world Y. Screen Y is zero at the topmost pixel and Screen.Height at the bottommost pixel.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.WW(System.Single)
member.summary: Converts screen width into world width. Screen width is measured in pixels.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Drawing.Canvas.WH(System.Single)
member.summary: Converts screen height into world height. Screen height is measured in pixels.

member.name: T:RT.Util.EggsML
member.summary: Implements a parser for the minimalist text mark-up language EggsML.

remarks.para: The “rules” of EggsML are, in summary:

item.description: In EggsML, the following non-alphanumeric characters are “special” (have meaning): ~ @ # $ % ^ & * _ = + / \ | [ ] { } < > ` "
All other characters are always literal.
All the special characters can be escaped by doubling them.
The characters ~ @ # $ % ^ & * _ = + / \ | [ { < can be used to open a “tag”.
Tags that start with [ { < are closed with ] } >. All other tags are closed with the same character.

Tags can be nested arbitrarily. In order to start a nested tag of the same character as its immediate parent, triple the tag character. For example, *one ***two* three* contains an asterisk tag nested inside another asterisk tag, while *one *two* three* would be parsed as two asterisk tags, one containing “one ” and the other containing “ three”.
The backtick character (`) can be used to “unjoin” multiple copies of the same character. For example, ** is a literal asterisk, but *`* is an empty tag containing no text.
The double-quote character (") can be used to escape long strings of special characters, e.g. URLs.

member.name: M:RT.Util.EggsML.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Parses the specified EggsML input.
member.param: The EggsML text to parse.
member.returns: The resulting parse-tree.

item.description: Tags are parsed into instances of .
The top-level nodes are contained in an instance of whose property is set to null.
All the literal text is parsed into instances of . All continuous text is consolidated, so there are no two consecutive EggsText instances in any list of children.

member.exception: Invalid syntax was encountered. The exception object contains the string index at which the error was detected.
was null.

member.name: M:RT.Util.EggsML.Escape(System.String)
member.summary: Escapes the input string such that it can be used in EggsML syntax. The result will either have no special characters in it or be entirely enclosed in double-quotes.

member.name: M:RT.Util.EggsML.WordWrap``1(RT.Util.EggsNode,``0,System.Int32,RT.Util.EggsML.EggMeasure{``0},RT.Util.EggsML.EggRender{``0},RT.Util.EggsML.EggNextLine{``0},RT.Util.EggsML.EggNextState{``0})
member.summary: Word-wraps a given piece of EggsML, assuming that it is linearly flowing text. Newline (\n) characters can be used to split the text into multiple paragraphs. See remarks for the special meaning of +...+ and <...>.
member.typeparam: The type of the text state that an EggsML can change, e.g. font or color.
member.param: The root node of the EggsML tree to word-wrap.
The initial text state.
The maximum width at which to word-wrap. This width can be measured in any unit, as long as uses the same unit.
A delegate that measures the width of any piece of text.
A delegate that is called whenever a piece of text is ready to be rendered.
A delegate that is called to advance to the next line.
A delegate that determines how each EggsML tag character modifies the state (font, color etc.).
member.returns: The maximum width of the text.

item.description: The +...+ tag marks text that may not be broken by wrapping (effectively turning all spaces into non-breaking spaces).
The <...> tag marks a parameter to an immediately following tag. For example, if the input EggsML contains <X>{Foo}, the text “X” will be passed as the parameter to when the { tag is processed.

member.name: T:RT.Util.EggsML.EggNextLine`1
member.summary: Provides a delegate for which advances to the next line.
member.typeparam: The type of the text state, e.g. font or color.
member.param: The state (font, color etc.) of the text.
‘true’ if a new paragraph begins, ‘false’ if a word is being wrapped within a paragraph.
If is false, the indentation of the current paragraph as measured only by its leading spaces; otherwise, zero.
member.returns: The indentation for the next line. Use this to implement, for example, hanging indents.

member.name: T:RT.Util.EggsML.EggNextState`1
member.summary: Provides a delegate for which determines how the text state (font, color etc.) changes for a given EggsML tag character. This delegate is called for all tags except for +...+ and <...>.
member.typeparam: The type of the text state, e.g. font or color.
member.param: The previous state (for the parent tag).
The EggsML tag character.
The contents of the immediately preceding <...> tag (if any), which can be used to parameterize other tags.
member.returns: The next state (return the old state for all tags that should not have a meaning) and an integer indicating the amount by which opening this tag has advanced the text position.

member.name: M:RT.Util.EggsNode.ToConsoleColoredStringWordWrap(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates a sequence of s from an EggsML parse tree by word-wrapping the output at a specified character width.
member.param: The number of characters at which to word-wrap the output.
The number of spaces to add to each line except the first of each paragraph, thus creating a hanging indentation.
member.returns: The sequence of s generated from the EggsML parse tree.

remarks.para: The following EggsML tags map to the following console colors:

item.description: ~ = black, or dark gray if inside a * tag
/ = dark blue, or blue if inside a * tag
$ = dark green, or green if inside a * tag
& = dark cyan, or cyan if inside a * tag
_ = dark red, or red if inside a * tag
% = dark magenta, or magenta if inside a * tag
^ = dark yellow, or yellow if inside a * tag
= = dark gray (independent of * tag)

remarks.para: Text which is not inside any of the above color tags defaults to light gray, or white if inside a * tag.

Additionally, the + tag can be used to suppress word-wrapping within a certain stretch of text. In other words, the contents of a + tag are treated as if they were a single word. Use this in preference to U+00A0 (no-break space) as it is more explicit and more future-compatible in case hyphenation is ever implemented here.

summary.para: Provides functionality similar to , but ensures that all conversions are lossless and roundtrippable. Whenever a conversion cannot be performed exactly, an is thrown.

remarks.code:
SUPPORTED TYPES
Supported types are classified as follows. The categories are used in defining the behaviour of the various conversion types and are vital to understanding what to expect of the corner cases.
Integer types: standard - byte, sbyte, short, ushort, int, uint, long, ulong, or any enum type bool - as integer this is defined exactly as 0 or 1 char - as integer this is the binary value of the char, identical to the "ushort" type datetime - as integer, this is the number of ticks of the datetime as UTC. The range is DateTime.MinValue.Ticks ... MaxValue.Ticks.
Fractional types: single, double decimal
String type: string
Unsupported type: any other type not listed above null reference (*ALWAYS* behaves exactly the same as if there was actually an object of an unsupported type)
Definition of terms: "succeed" / "fail" - these terms do not specify the method by which the outcome of a conversion is conveyed. This is a separate aspect discussed later.
ExactConvert only allows a conversion to succeed if a roundtrip conversion would result in at most a very small error. The "very small error" only exists when a Fractional type is the destination - in this case, ExactConvert picks the nearest representable value.
A general trait of ExactConvert is that the rules are defined for whole source/destination type pairs. A necessary exception to this principle is conversion from string, due to the arbitrary nature of string values.
As a consequence of the above principle, ExactConvert does not allow Fractional types to be converted to Integer types.
Something to beware of: some of the built-in conversions use national strings for values, e.g. for True/False/Infinity etc. To avoid any issues like programs crashing on Spanish computers but not on British ones, the following strings are hard-coded. All conversions _from_ strings are case-insensitive.
* True * False * Inf * NaN

member.summary: Returns true if the specified type is integer-compatible (in other words, a string of digits can be converted to it using ). This includes all types that are as well as DateTime, Char and Boolean.
member.param: The type to be tested.

member.summary: Returns true if the specified type is integer-compatible (in other words, a string of digits can be converted to it using ). This includes all types that are as well as DateTime, Char and Boolean.
member.param: The code of the type to be tested - use to get the code of an object's type.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExactConvert.UnboxIntegerToLong(System.Object)
member.summary:
C# does not allow a boxed integer type to be unboxed as anything other than the true type of the boxed integer. This utility function unboxes the integer as the correct type and then casts it to a long, returning the result.
Throws an exception if the object is null or not one of the built-in integer types.
Does not support unboxing of a ulong because the cast to long would be lossy and misleading. Will throw an exception when given a boxed ulong.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExactConvert.UnboxIntegerToLong(System.Object,System.TypeCode)
member.summary: A faster version of UnboxIntegerToLong(object) if the TypeCode is already provided. Behaviour is undefined if typeCode does not match the type of the object passed in.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExactConvert.GetTypeCode(System.Object)
member.summary:
Crutches needed all around... TypeCode.Empty is described as the type code for "a null reference". Unfortunately the only way to retrieve a TypeCode is from a Type object, which can't represent the type of a null reference (well... actually one can't really talk about a _type_ of a _null_ reference in C# at all as far as I understand).
Well anyway, wrapping up the rant, this function fills in the spot of a function that's clearly missing: Type.GetTypeCode(object), which returns TypeCode.Empty if asked to get the type of a null object.
Something at the back of my mind tells me that there's one way of looking at this where the behaviour of the existing API would make sense... but really, I think this is how it really should have been since it is a lot more useful.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExactConvert.Try(System.Object,System.String@)
member.summary:
Converts the specified object to a string.
Returns true if successful, or false if the object cannot be converted exactly. is set to the type's default value if the conversion is unsuccessful, which in this case means null (!!!).
Note that the result will only ever be false if the value is one of the unsupported types - all supported types can be converted to a string. (So can the unsupported ones but it's a different matter. Unsupported types are not supported by this method for consistency with the other overloads.)

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.CollectionExtensions.BinarySearch``2(System.Collections.Generic.SortedList{``0,``1},``0,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Performs a binary search for the specified key on a . When no match exists, returns the nearest indices for interpolation/extrapolation purposes.
member.remarks: If an exact match exists, index1 == index2 == the index of the match. If an exact match is not found, index1 < index2. If the key is less than every key in the list, index1 is int.MinValue and index2 is 0. If it's greater than every key, index1 = last item index and index2 = int.MaxValue. Otherwise index1 and index2 are the indices of the items that would surround the key were it present in the list.
member.param: List to operate on.
The key to look for.
Receives the value of the first index (see remarks).
Receives the value of the second index (see remarks).

member.remarks: This method replaces IEnumerable{T}.Select{TSource, TResult}(IEnumerable{TSource},Func{TSource,int,TResult}) for the case where the input is a ListSelectIterator<TInput, TResult> with an implementation that makes a subsequent ToArray() or ToList() run 15% faster.

member.name: T:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDateFormat
member.summary: Defines one of several common date/time formats which are either ISO-8601 compatible or very slight deviations from it.

member.name: F:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDateFormat.HumanReadable
member.summary: A delimited, readable format. Known as "extended" in ISO-8601. Example: 2007-12-31 21:15.

member.name: F:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDateFormat.Compact
member.summary: A non-delimited compact format. Known as "basic" in ISO-8601. Example: 20071231T2115.

member.name: F:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDateFormat.CompactReadable
member.summary: A non-delimited compact format with '-' instead of 'T'. Not ISO-8601, but supported by . Example: 20071231-2115.

member.name: F:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDateFormat.FilenameReadable
member.summary: A delimited, readable format without spaces usable in filenames. Not ISO-8601, and not supported by . Example: 2007.12.31-21.15.

member.name: F:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDateFormat.Iso8601
member.summary: The standard ISO-8601 format. Example: 2007-12-31T21:15.

member.name: T:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDatePrecision
member.summary: Defines a precision for a date/time stamp.

member.name: F:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDatePrecision.Days
member.summary: Day precision: 2011-12-31

member.name: F:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDatePrecision.Minutes
member.summary: Minute precision: 2011-12-31 18:03

member.name: F:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDatePrecision.Seconds
member.summary: Second precision: 2011-12-31 18:03:15

member.name: F:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDatePrecision.Milliseconds
member.summary: Millisecond precision: 2011-12-31 18:03:15.123

member.name: F:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDatePrecision.Full
member.summary: The full .NET DateTime precision, which is seconds to 7 d.p. (100-nanosecond intervals): 2011-12-31 18:03:15.1234567

member.name: T:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.DateTimeExtensions
member.summary: Provides extension methods on the type.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.DateTimeExtensions.Nanosecond(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Inexplicably, the DateTime type does not offer any way of retrieving the full precision of the underlying data other than via Ticks or the ToString method. This extension method fills in the void.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.DateTimeExtensions.ToIsoStringCustom(System.DateTime,RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDatePrecision,System.Nullable{System.Char},System.Nullable{System.Char},System.Nullable{System.Char},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns a string representation of the date/time in an ISO-8601-like format. The date/time components are always ordered from largest (year) to smallest (nanoseconds), and they are always specified as a fixed-width numeric value. The separators between the parts can be customized.
member.param: Date/time to convert.
Which date/time components are to be included. The values are truncated, not rounded.
The character to insert between years, months and days, or null for none.
The character to insert between hours, minutes and seconds (including timezone offset), or null for none.
The character to insert between the date and the time part, or null for none (which is never valid in ISO-8601).
Specifies whether a suffix indicating date/time kind (local/utc/unspecified) and, for local times, a UTC offset, is appended.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.DateTimeExtensions.ToIsoString(System.DateTime,RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDatePrecision,RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDateFormat,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns a string representation of the date/time in an ISO-8601 compatible (or very close) format.
member.param: Date/time to convert.
Which date/time components are to be included. The values are truncated, not rounded.
One of the several pre-defined formats to use.
Specifies whether a suffix indicating date/time kind (local/utc/unspecified) and, for local times, a UTC offset, is appended.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.DateTimeExtensions.ToIsoStringOptimal(System.DateTime,RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDateFormat,RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDatePrecision,RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDatePrecision,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns a string representation of the date/time in an ISO-8601-like format. The function will omit higher-precision parts whose values are zeroes, as permitted by the standard.
member.param: Date/time to convert.
One of the several pre-defined formats to use.
Minimum precision of the resulting string. The actual precision is determined by what's available in the date/time, bounded by this parameter.
Maximum precision of the resulting string. Any higher-precision parts are truncated.
Specifies whether a suffix indicating date/time kind (local/utc/unspecified) and, for local times, a UTC offset, is appended.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.DateTimeExtensions.ToIsoStringRoundtrip(System.DateTime,RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDateFormat,RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.IsoDatePrecision)
member.summary: Returns a string representation of the date/time in an ISO-8601-like format. Use this if the result must be round-trippable without losing any information. The function will omit higher-precision parts whose values are zeroes, as permitted by the standard.
member.param: Date/time to convert.
One of the several pre-defined formats to use.
Minimum precision of the resulting string. The actual precision is determined by what's available in the date/time, bounded by this parameter.

summary.para: Attempts to parse the specified string as an ISO-formatted DateTime. The formats supported are guided by ISO-8601, but do not match it exactly. Strings with no timezone information are parsed into DateTimeKind.Unspecified.
ISO-8601 features not supported: day numbers; week numbers; time offsets; comma for decimal separation.
Features supported not in ISO-8601: '-' separator for the basic format; date shortening; timezone marker for date-only strings.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.DateTimeExtensions.ParseIsoNullable(System.String)
member.summary: Parse the specified string as an ISO-formatted DateTime. Returns null if the string is null or cannot be parsed. See for more info.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.StreamExtensions.WriteInt32Optim(System.IO.Stream,System.Int32)
member.summary: Encodes a 32-bit signed integer in a variable number of bytes, using fewer bytes for values closer to zero.

remarks.para: Writes an integer 7 bits at a time. This allows small integers to be stored in 1 byte, longer ones in 2, at the cost of storing the longest ones in 5 bytes.
Example for a positive int:
becomes three bytes:
Example for a negative int:
becomes three bytes:
Note how an extra byte is needed in this example. This is similar to requiring a sign bit, however this way the positive values are directly compatible with unsigned Optim values.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.StreamExtensions.WriteUInt32Optim(System.IO.Stream,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Encodes a 32-bit unsigned integer in a variable number of bytes, using fewer bytes for smaller values.
member.remarks: See for the precise encoding.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.StreamExtensions.WriteInt64Optim(System.IO.Stream,System.Int64)
member.summary: Encodes a 64-bit signed integer in a variable number of bytes, using fewer bytes for values closer to zero.
member.remarks: See for the precise encoding.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.StreamExtensions.WriteUInt64Optim(System.IO.Stream,System.UInt64)
member.summary: Encodes a 64-bit unsigned integer in a variable number of bytes, using fewer bytes for smaller values.
member.remarks: See for the precise encoding.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.StreamExtensions.WriteDecimalOptim(System.IO.Stream,System.Decimal)
member.summary: Encodes a decimal in a variable number of bytes, using fewer bytes for frequently-occurring low-precision values.

remarks.para: The first byte is a "header" byte. Its top bit indicates the sign of the value, while the remaining 7 bits encode the scale and the length, in bytes, of the mantissa component. Since the scale can be anything between 0..28 and the length can be up to 12, this number is simply an index into a lookup table which contains specific combinations of both values. These combinations were selected by analyzing the actual distribution of mantissa length + exponent pairs making a few assumptions about the likely inputs into arithmetic operations. The encoder makes sure to select a value representing the exact scale and the minimum representable mantissa length.
The result is always at most 13 bytes long, which is the same as discarding the three unused bytes of the raw representation.

member.name: M:RT.Util.ExtensionMethods.StringExtensions.WordWrap(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Word-wraps the current string to a specified width. Supports UNIX-style newlines and indented paragraphs.

remarks.para: The supplied text will be split into "paragraphs" at the newline characters. Every paragraph will begin on a new line in the word-wrapped output, indented by the same number of spaces as in the input. All subsequent lines belonging to that paragraph will also be indented by the same amount.
All multiple contiguous spaces will be replaced with a single space (except for the indentation).

member.param: Text to be word-wrapped.
The maximum number of characters permitted on a single line, not counting the end-of-line terminator.
The number of spaces to add to each line except the first of each paragraph, thus creating a hanging indentation.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage
member.summary: Holds a number of settings that define a message dialog. Provides a method to show the dialog represented, as well as static methods to show some common dialog kinds with most settings at their defaults.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.Type
member.summary: Specifies the message type. This selects a sound, an image and a caption to be used by default, unless explicitly overridden in the other fields of this class. Defaults to .

member.name: F:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.Buttons
member.summary: Specifies the labels of the buttons to be displayed in the dialog. Defaults to null, in which case a single "OK" button will appear. May contain at most four elements. The labels may include the ampersand to indicate a shortcut key, or double-ampersand to include an ampersand.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.Message
member.summary: Specifies the message to be displayed in the main message area. Defaults to null, in which case the message area will be empty.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.Caption
member.summary: Specifies a caption to be displayed in the dialog's window title bar. Defaults to null, which means choose a title based on the field.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.Image
member.summary: Specifies an image to be displayed in the image area of the dialog. Defaults to null, which means use an image based on the field. If the type is , and this field is null, no image will be displayed.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.Font
member.summary: Specifies a font to be used for the message text (but not the buttons). Defaults to null, which means the default system font should be used.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.AcceptButton
member.summary: Specifies the index of the accept button (the one selected if the user just presses Enter). Defaults to -1, which means the button with index 0.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.CancelButton
member.summary: Specifies the index of the cancel button (the one selected if the user just presses Esc or Alt+F4). Defaults to -1, which means the button with the largest valid index.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.ShowInTaskbar
member.summary: Specifies whether a taskbar icon is shown for the dialog box.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.Show
member.summary: Shows a message using all the settings specified in this class instance. Anything left at defaults will be modified to hold the appropriate value. Any invalid settings will be flagged with an exception.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.Show(System.String,RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgType)
member.summary: Shows a message of the specified message type, using an appropriate caption, sound and image.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.Show(System.String,System.String,RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgType,System.String[])
member.summary: Shows a message of the specified message type, using an appropriate sound and image.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.ShowInfo(System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Shows an informational message using the image, caption and sound appropriate for this message type.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.ShowQuestion(System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Shows a question message using the image, caption and sound appropriate for this message type.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.ShowWarning(System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Shows a warning message using the image, caption and sound appropriate for this message type.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.ShowError(System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Shows an error message using the image, caption and sound appropriate for this message type.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.deduceAndCheckSettings
member.summary: Verifies that all the settings are correct, throwing an exception if not. For all settings left at defaults, stores a value deemed appropriate based on the other settings.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.showAsIs
member.summary: Creates a message form and fills in the controls using the current settings. Does not verify whether the settings are valid, so must only be used internally and only after the settings have been verified.
member.returns: The index of the button pressed.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Dialogs.DlgMessage.Translate(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Applies a translation to certain default strings, on the assumption that all messages are to be shown with the same translation.
member.param: Translation for the default "OK" button.
Translation for the default window caption for informational messages.
Translation for the default window caption for question messages.
Translation for the default window caption for warning messages.
Translation for the default window caption for error messages.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Forms.ManagedForm.ResizeAndReposition(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Override to alter the window size, maximize state and/or position on first show and screen resolution changes. At the time of call, the current position/state/size are already set to the preferred ones, so it is possible to change them with respect to the "saved" values. If this method does nothing then the last saved values will be in effect.
member.param: True if this is the first time the form is displayed; false if it's a screen resolution change.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Forms.ManagedWindow
member.summary: A window which has all the proper minimize/restore methods, and which remembers its position and size between instances of the application. The size/position/state values are automatically reflected in the settings object whenever the user resizes or moves the window. If XAML supplies an initial size, that size will be used whenever no previous size is available (such as first run).

member.summary: To make the window maximized by default (i.e. on first run, before the user has had a chance to move/resize the window), override this property and return true. This property is read from the window constructor. Do not use XAML to set Maximized to true because will not be able to override that without flicker (and thus doesn't support that at all).

member.name: T:RT.Util.Geometry.GeomUt
member.summary: Contains general geometry-related utility functions.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Geometry.GeomUt.NormalizedAngle(System.Double)
member.summary: "Unwinds" the specified angle so that it's in the range (-pi, pi]

member.name: M:RT.Util.Geometry.GeomUt.AngleDifference(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns "angle" relative to "reference". I.e. if the angles are the same, returns 0; if angle is further anticlockwise, returns a positive number.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Geometry.GeomUt.ArePointsSameSideOfLine(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary:
Given a vector l, and two points pt1 and pt2, splits the space into two halves on the line defined by the vector l. If both points lie in the same half, returns true. If they lie in different halves, or if at least one point lies on the dividing line, returns false.
If the vector l is of length 0, always returns false.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Geometry.Intersect
member.summary:
A utility class to find / test for intersections between geometric shapes.
In this static class, function names always have the two basic shapes ordered using the following order:
Line (infinite)
Ray (starts at a point, extends to infinity)
Segment (starts and ends on finite points)
Circle
BoundingBox (axis-aligned, ordered coords of each edge are known)
Hence it's always LineWithCircle, never CircleWithLine.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Geometry.Intersect.LineWithLine(RT.Util.Geometry.EdgeD@,RT.Util.Geometry.EdgeD@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Finds the point of intersection of two lines. The result is in terms of lambda along each of the lines. Point of intersection is defined as "line.Start + lambda * line", for each line. If the lines don't intersect, the lambdas are set to NaN.

summary.para: Finds the point of intersection between two lines, specified by two points each.
If the lines coincide or are parallel, returns (NaN,NaN).

member.name: M:RT.Util.Geometry.Intersect.LineWithCircle(RT.Util.Geometry.EdgeD@,RT.Util.Geometry.CircleD@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Finds the points of intersection between a line and a circle. The results are two lambdas along the line, one for each point, or NaN if there is no intersection.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Geometry.Intersect.LineWithCircle(RT.Util.Geometry.EdgeD,RT.Util.Geometry.CircleD,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Finds the points of intersection between a line and a circle. The results are two lambdas along the line, one for each point, or NaN if there is no intersection.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Geometry.Intersect.RayWithSegment(RT.Util.Geometry.EdgeD@,RT.Util.Geometry.EdgeD@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Calculates the intersection of a ray with a segment. Returns the result as the lambdas of the intersection point along the ray and the segment. If there is no intersection returns double.NaN in both lambdas.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Geometry.Intersect.RayWithCircle(RT.Util.Geometry.EdgeD@,RT.Util.Geometry.CircleD@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Finds the points of intersection between a ray and a circle. The resulting lambdas along the ray are sorted in ascending order, so the "first" intersection is always in lambda1 (if any). Lambda may be NaN if there is no intersection (or no "second" intersection).

member.name: M:RT.Util.Geometry.Intersect.RayWithArc(RT.Util.Geometry.EdgeD@,RT.Util.Geometry.ArcD@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Finds the points of intersection between a ray and an arc. The resulting lambdas along the ray are sorted in ascending order, so the "first" intersection is always in lambda1 (if any). Lambda may be NaN if there is no intersection (or no "second" intersection).

member.name: M:RT.Util.Geometry.Intersect.RayWithRectangle(RT.Util.Geometry.EdgeD@,RT.Util.Geometry.RectangleD@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Finds intersections between a ray and a rectangle. Returns the lambdas of intersections, if any, or NaN otherwise. Guarantees that lambda1 < lambda2, and if only one of them is NaN then it's lambda2. Lambda is such that ray.Start + lambda * (ray.End - ray.Start) gives the point of intersection.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Geometry.Intersect.RayWithBoundingBox(RT.Util.Geometry.EdgeD@,RT.Util.Geometry.BoundingBoxD@)
member.summary: Checks for intersections between a ray and a bounding box. Returns true if there is at least one intersection.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Geometry.Intersect.SegmentWithSegment(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary:
If the two specified line segments touch anywhere, returns true. Otherwise returns false.
Support for zero-length segments is partial - if one of the segments is of length 0 the result is correct, but if both are the result is always true.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Geometry.Intersect.BoundingBoxWithBoundingBox(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Checks for intersections between the two bounding boxes specified by the coordinates. Returns true if there is at least one intersection. Coordinates ending with "1" belong to the first box, "2" to the second one. Coordinates starting with "f" MUST be less than or equal to ones starting with "t".

member.name: M:RT.Util.Geometry.Intersect.BoundingBoxWithBoundingBox(RT.Util.Geometry.BoundingBoxD@,RT.Util.Geometry.BoundingBoxD@)
member.summary: Checks for intersections between the two bounding boxes specified by the coordinates. Returns true if there is at least one intersection.

member.summary: Prompts the user for input.

member.summary: Specifies the degree of strictness or leniency when converting a to a numerical type such as int or double.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Json.NumericConversionOptions.Strict
member.summary: The conversion only succeeds if the object is a and its value is exactly representable by the target type.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Json.NumericConversionOptions.AllowConversionFromString
member.summary: The conversion succeeds if the object is a with numerical content.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Json.NumericConversionOptions.AllowZeroFractionToInteger
member.summary: Ignored unless is also specified. A conversion to an integer type succeeds if the string contains a decimal followed by a zero fractional part.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Json.NumericConversionOptions.AllowConversionFromBool
member.summary: The conversion succeeds if the object is a , which will convert to 0 if false and 1 if true.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Json.NumericConversionOptions.AllowTruncation
member.summary: Allows conversion of non-integral numbers to integer types by truncation (rounding towards zero). If is specified, strings containing a decimal part are also converted and truncated when converting to an integer type.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Json.JsonValue.Fmt(System.String,RT.Util.Json.JsonValue[])
member.summary: Formats JSON values into a piece of JavaScript code and then removes almost all unnecessary whitespace and comments. Values are referenced by names; placeholders for these values are written as {{name}}. Placeholders are only replaced outside of JavaScript literal strings and regexes. instances are inserted unmodified.
member.param: JavaScript code with placeholders.
Alternating names and associated values, for example ["user", "abc"] specifies one value named "user".
member.exception: has an odd number of values. OR contains a {{placeholder}} whose name is not listed in .
is null. OR is null.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Json.JsonNumber
member.summary: Encapsulates a number, which may be a floating-point number or an integer, as a . See Remarks.
member.remarks: JSON does not define any specific limits for numeric values. This implementation supports integers in the signed 64-bit range, as well as IEEE 64-bit doubles (except NaNs and infinities). Conversions to/from decimal are exact for integers, but can be approximate for non-integers, depending on the exact value.

member.summary: Provides a type descriptor which supports translation of various string values using the Lingo conventions (see remarks).
member.typeparam: The type of the translation class.
member.remarks: Every property requiring translatable name/description/category should have a corresponding method in the same class. This method should be static, named the same as the property with a "Tr" suffix, take a translation instance and return a .

member.summary: Constructs a type description provider using the specified translation getter.
member.param: A function that returns the currently active translation.

member.summary: Override; see base.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Lingo.LingoEnumConverter`2
member.summary: Provides a base implementation for enum converters intended to enable enum translation. See remarks.
member.typeparam: Type of the enum being translated.
Type of a translation class which has fields named the same as enum values.
member.remarks: Suggested use: define a separate Lingo string class for the enum. Inside this class, declare a nested class deriving from this base class. Specify a TypeConverter on the enum in question using the said nested class.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.LingoEnumConverter`2.#ctor(System.Func{`1})
member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: A method which returns the currently active translation for this enum.

member.summary: Override; see base.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1
member.summary: Helps an application using Lingo to display language selection UI.
member.typeparam: The type of the class holding the program’s translation.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Func{RT.Util.Lingo.Language})
member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: The title of the program - to be displayed in the translation UI.
Name of the module being translated - used to construct the filename for the translation file.
Whether translation editing UI should be included.
A callback that returns the currently active language whenever called.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.SetLanguage(RT.Util.Lingo.Language)
member.summary: Changes the currently selected language in exactly the same way as using one of the UI elements would.
member.param: The desired language. If not available, the default language will be set instead.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.FireTranslationChanged(`0)
member.summary: Triggers the event with the specified translation.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.MayExitApplication
member.summary: Returns a value indicating whether it is okay to close the application. The user is asked if there are any unsaved changes.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.CloseWithoutPrompts
member.summary: Closes the translation dialog (if it is visible) without any prompts regarding unsaved changes.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.ListCurrentEntries
member.summary: Returns a list of UI control descriptors whose state is applicable at the time of invocation. This method should be invoked every time prior to displaying UI, to obtain the up-to-date UI state. The entries returned are not "live" and will not be updated to reflect any changes.
member.remarks: The list is guaranteed to have at least one item, the default language. Exactly one item will have set to true.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.CreateNewLanguage
member.summary: Opens the dialog for creating a new language.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.EditCurrentLanguage
member.summary: Opens the GUI for editing the translation in the current language.

member.name: E:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.TranslationChanged
member.summary: Occurs whenever the translation has been changed. The application must respond by updating *all* visible UI and storing the language of the selected translation for use on next program start.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.Entry
member.summary: Describes a UI entry exposed by the language helper.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.Entry.Text
member.summary: The label that the control should have. Hotkeys are prefixed with an ampersand; ampersands are escaped by doubling.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.Entry.SeparatorBefore
member.summary: If true, a separator should be displayed before this control, if possible.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.Entry.IsCurrentLanguage
member.summary: The UI control should appear highlighted or checked, because it represents the current language.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.Entry.Enabled
member.summary: Whether the UI control should be enabled (that is, possible to trigger the ).

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.Entry.#ctor(RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper{`0},RT.Util.Lingo.Language)
member.summary: Constructor for language entries.

member.summary: Constructor for arbitrary entries.

member.summary: Returns the UI control text.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.Entry.Language
member.summary: If this UI entry activates a language, this is the language code. Otherwise null.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Lingo.LanguageHelper`1.Entry.Action
member.summary: Activating the control should invoke this action.
