member.name: T:RT.Util.Lingo.Lingo
member.summary: Static class with helper methods to support multi-language applications.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Lingo.Lingo.AlsoSaveTranslationsTo
member.summary: If not null, whenever a translation is saved, Lingo will also attempt to save it in this directory. Use an absolute path. Lingo will quietly ignore any errors when saving here, and will do nothing if the path is missing. Lingo will overwrite read-only files without prompts.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.Lingo.LoadTranslationOrDefault``1(System.String,RT.Util.Lingo.Language@)
member.summary: Attempts to load the translation for the specified module and language. The translation must exist in the application executable directory under a subdirectory called "Translations". If the translation loaded successfully, returns the translation instance. Otherwise, the default constructor is called and the result returned, and is set to the default language returned by this constructor.
member.typeparam: The type of the translation class to load the translation into.
member.param: The name of the module whose translation to load.
The language code of the language to load. This is set to the default language if the specified language cannot be loaded.
member.returns: The loaded or default translation.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.Lingo.LoadTranslation``1(System.String,RT.Util.Lingo.Language)
member.summary: Loads and returns the translation for the specified module and language. The translation must exist in the application executable directory under a subdirectory called "Translations". If the translation cannot be loaded successfully, an exception is thrown.
member.typeparam: The type of the translation class to load the translation into.
member.param: The name of the module whose translation to load.
The language code of the language to load.
member.returns: The loaded translation.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Lingo.Lingo.LoadTranslation(System.Type,System.String,RT.Util.Lingo.Language)
member.summary: Loads and returns the translation for the specified module and language. The translation must exist in the application executable directory under a subdirectory called "Translations". If the translation cannot be loaded successfully, an exception is thrown.
member.param: The type of the translation class to load the translation into.
The name of the module whose translation to load.
The language code of the language to load.
member.returns: The loaded translation.

member.summary: Writes the specified translation for the specified module to an XML file in the application directory.

member.param: Name of the module for which this is a translation.
The translation to save.

member.param: Post-build step reporter.

member.name: T:RT.Util.LoggerBase
member.summary: Abstract base class for all loggers. Implements some common functionality.
member.remarks: Use a lock on this object to make several consecutive logging operations atomic.

member.name: F:RT.Util.LoggerBase.VerbosityLimit
member.summary: Holds the current verbosity limit for each of the log types. Only messages with same or lower verbosity will be printed. Defaults to level 1 for all messages except debug, which defaults to 0.
member.remarks: Applications can print a message with a verbosity level of 0 - such messages cannot be disabled.

member.name: F:RT.Util.LoggerBase.TimestampFormat
member.summary: Holds a format string for printing the date/time at which a log entry was added. Defaults to a full ISO-formatted date/time string with milliseconds.

member.name: F:RT.Util.LoggerBase.MessageFormat
member.summary: Holds a format string for the log information message. This will receive the following arguments: {0}: timestamp, {1}: message type string, {2}: message verbosity level. The actual message will be printed immediately after the log information message.

member.name: F:RT.Util.LoggerBase.IndentFormatSuffix
member.summary: When printing multi-line (e.g. wrapped) messages, the indent text will consist of a number of spaces and end with this suffix.

member.name: F:RT.Util.LoggerBase.TimestampInUTC
member.summary: If true, the timestamps will be printed in UTC. Otherwise in local time. Defaults to false.

member.name: M:RT.Util.LoggerBase.#ctor
member.summary: Initialises some members to their default values.

member.name: M:RT.Util.LoggerBase.GetMessageTypeString(RT.Util.LogType)
member.summary: Specifies a short string describing each log type (INFO, WARN, ERROR, or DEBUG).

member.name: M:RT.Util.LoggerBase.ConfigureVerbosity(System.String)
member.summary: Takes a string which encodes verbosity limit configuration, parses it and sets the limits accordingly. On failure throws an ArgumentException with a fairly detailed description of the string format.

remarks.para: Examples of valid strings:

item.description: sets default values
sets all limits to 3
sets all limits to 2, then set the debug limit to 0
sets info=0, warning=1, error=2, debug=3

remarks.para: Intended use: configuring the logger via a command-line option.

member.name: M:RT.Util.LoggerBase.GetFormattedStrings(System.String@,System.String@,System.UInt32,RT.Util.LogType)
member.summary: Helps prepare a log message to the derived classes. Takes the parameters supplied by a call to one of the Log methods and generates two strings: the which is the message header and the which is the indent text.

member.name: M:RT.Util.LoggerBase.Log(System.UInt32,RT.Util.LogType,System.String)
member.summary: Appends an entry to the log. Derived classes implement this to put the log data where necessary.
member.remarks: Note that the various specialised functions such as simply call this method to do the work.
member.param: Verbosity level of this message.
Message type (info, warning, error or debug).
The message itself.

member.name: T:RT.Util.MultipartFormDataHelper
member.summary: Simplifies submitting POST requests with data encoded in the multipart/form-data format. See Remarks.
member.remarks: The simplest use example is to create a web request using (HttpWebRequest) WebRequest.Create(...), add the data using and methods, and complete the request using .

member.name: M:RT.Util.MultipartFormDataHelper.#ctor(System.Net.HttpWebRequest)
member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: The request to be used for the form data submission. This class automatically sets several fields which should not be modified by the caller afterwards. These are: Method, ContentType. You MUST NOT call or on this request. You may modify request headers until the first call to an Add* method.

member.name: M:RT.Util.MultipartFormDataHelper.GetResponse
member.summary: Finalizes the request and sends it to the remote host (or, if the request is not buffered, ensures the entire request has been sent). Waits for response and returns the response object.

member.name: M:RT.Util.MultipartFormDataHelper.AddField(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a named text value to the POST request.
member.param: The name of the value to add. For maximum compatibility with servers, use only printable ASCII characters in this name. This field is encoded using UTF-8, which is supported by some modern servers, but not by others.
The content to add as the value. Note that this is interpreted as Unicode text, and is a poor choice for binary data. For binary data, see .

member.name: M:RT.Util.MultipartFormDataHelper.AddFile(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a named file (or, generally, a binary data field) to the POST request.
member.param: The name of the value to add. For maximum compatibility with servers, use only printable ASCII characters in this name. This field is encoded using UTF-8, which is supported by some modern servers, but not by others.

The filename to use. The server may interpret this as it pleases, but this value will often end up being exposed as the name of the uploaded file. For maximum compatibility with servers, use only printable ASCII characters in this name. This field is encoded using UTF-8, which is supported by some modern servers, but not by others.
The content type to specify for this data/file. Some servers decide whether to accept or reject an upload based on the content type. Specify null to prevent the inclusion of the Content-Type header.
member.returns: A stream into which the binary data is to be written. You may close this stream when done, but if you don't, it will be closed automatically next time you add a field or a file, or if you call (which prevents further writing).

member.name: M:RT.Util.MultipartFormDataHelper.AddFile(System.String,System.String,System.Byte[],System.String)
member.summary: Adds a named file (or, generally, a binary data field) to the POST request.
member.param: The name of the value to add. For maximum compatibility with servers, use only printable ASCII characters in this name. This field is encoded using UTF-8, which is supported by some modern servers, but not by others.

The filename to use. The server may interpret this as it pleases, but this value will often end up being exposed as the name of the uploaded file. For maximum compatibility with servers, use only printable ASCII characters in this name. This field is encoded using UTF-8, which is supported by some modern servers, but not by others.
The binary data to send as the content of this file.
The content type to specify for this data/file. Some servers decide whether to accept or reject an upload based on the content type. Specify null to prevent the inclusion of the Content-Type header.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Paths.PathManager
member.summary: Maintains a selection of paths in the filesystem and offers methods for enumerating all the included paths and/or files.

remarks.para: Initially empty. Paths may be added to the set (with all subpaths) by calling , and removed from the set using (again, with subpaths). The order of these calls is important.
There is currently no support for including or excluding non-recursively, nor for including/excluding specific files.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Paths.PathManager.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs an empty instance.

member.summary: Constructs an instance containing all of the specified paths (with all subpaths).

member.summary: Creates a deep clone of this class.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Paths.PathManager.findPathEntry(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the index of the specified path or -1 if not found

member.summary: Makes the specified path and all subpaths included into the set of paths.

member.summary: Makes the specified path and all subpaths excluded from the set of paths.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Paths.PathManager.Include(System.String)

member.name: M:RT.Util.Paths.PathManager.Reset
member.summary: Resets the set of paths to a state where all paths are excluded.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Paths.PathManager.IsPathIncluded(System.String)

member.summary: If assigned, this delegate will be called whenever a directory cannot be enumerated, e.g. due to being unreadable etc. This function must return "false" in order to terminate scanning or "true" to continue.

member.summary: Paths which could not be read while enumerating PathManager. Automatically cleared before each enumeration.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Paths.PathManager.GetEntries
member.summary: Enumerates all files and directories according to the paths that were added using and . If any paths cannot be enumerated, they are added to the list, which is cleared before enumeration begins.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Paths.PathManager.GetFiles
member.summary: Enumerates all files (not folders) according to the paths that were added using and . If any paths cannot be enumerated, they are added to the list, which is cleared before enumeration begins.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Paths.PathManager.GetDirectories
member.summary: Enumerates all directories (not files) according to the paths that were added using and . If any paths cannot be enumerated, they are added to the list, which is cleared before enumeration begins.

Path to be compared

member.param: Path to be normalised.
member.returns: Normalised version of , or null if the input was null.

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.IsSubpathOf(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Checks whether refers to a subdirectory inside .

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.IsSubpathOfOrSame(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Checks whether refers to a subdirectory inside or the same directory.

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.ExpandPath(System.String)
member.summary: Expands all occurrences of "$(NAME)" in the specified string with the special folder path for the current machine/user. See remarks for details.

remarks.para: Expands all occurrences of "$(NAME)", where NAME is the name of one of the values of the enum. There is no support for escaping such a replacement, and invalid names are ignored.
The following additional names are also recognised:

item.description: expands to the system's temporary folder path (Path.GetTempPath()).
expands to the directory containing the entry assembly (Assembly.GetEntryAssembly()). Throws an if there is no entry assembly (e.g. in a secondary app domain).

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.UnexpandPath(System.String)
member.summary: Checks to see whether the specified path starts with any of the standard paths supported by , and if so, replaces the prefix with a "$(NAME)" string and returns the resulting value. The value passed in should be an absolute path for the substitution to work.

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.DeleteEmptyDirs(System.String)
member.summary: Deletes the specified directory only if it is empty, and then checks all parents to see if they have become empty too. If so, deletes them too. Does not throw any exceptions.

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.ExtractParent(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the "parent" path of the specified path by removing the last name from the path, separated by either forward or backslash. If the original path ends in slash, the returned path will also end with a slash.

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.ExtractParent(System.String,System.Char)
member.summary: Returns the "parent" path of the specified path by removing the last group from the path, separated by the "separator" character. If the original path ends in slash, the returned path will also end with a slash.

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.ExtractNameAndExt(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the name and extension of the last group in the specified path, separated by either of the two slashes.

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.Combine(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Joins the two paths using the OS separator character. If the second path is absolute, only the second path is returned.

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.Combine(System.String,System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Joins multiple paths using the OS separator character. If any of the paths is absolute, all preceding paths are discarded.

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.CreatePathToFile(System.String)
member.summary: Creates all directories in the path to the specified file if they don't exist. Accepts filenames relative to the current directory.

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.StripTrailingSeparator(System.String)
member.summary: Strips a single trailing directory separator, whether it's the forward- or backslash. Preserves the single separator at the end of paths referring to the root of a drive, such as "C:\". Removes at most a single separator, never more.

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.ToggleRelative(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Changes a relative to an absolute and vice versa, with respect to . Neither path must be an empty string. Any trailing slashes are ignored and the result won't have one except for root "C:\"-style paths. Forward slashes, multiple repeated slashes, and any redundant "." or ".." elements are correctly interpreted and eliminated. See Remarks for some special cases.
member.remarks: Relative paths that specify a drive letter "C:thing" are not supported and result in undefined behaviour. If the toggled path is relative then all ".." levels that expand beyond the root directory are silently discarded.
member.param: An absolute path to the directory which serves as the base for absolute/relative conversion.
An absolute or a relative path to be converted.
member.returns: The converted path.
member.exception: Conversion could not be performed for the reason specified in the exception object.

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.AppendBeforeExtension(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Appends the specified value to the filename part before extension.
member.param: Filename to which the value should be appended.
The value to append.

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.ExpandWildcards(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Given a filename or a pattern containing * or ? wildcards, enumerates all names matching the wildcard.
member.param: The filename or pattern to expand. If this doesn't contain any wildcards, it is returned unchanged, even if the named file/directory does not exist in the file system. The pattern may include an absolute or a relative path, or contain just a name; the results will be relative iff the pattern was relative, and will contain no path iff the pattern didn't.
Specifies that the pattern should match existing files.
Specifies that the pattern should match existing directories.
Indicates that files contained in subdirectories should be included.

member.name: M:RT.Util.PathUtil.GetFullPath(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the full path pointing to the same file/directory as . Converts relative paths to absolute paths where necessary, relative to the current working directory. This is the same as , except that this function returns the actual on-disk capitalization for each segment, regardless of how they are capitalized in . If the path does not exist in full, corrects the capitalization of the segments that do exist. Always capitalizes the drive letter.

member.name: P:RT.Util.PathUtil.AppPath
member.summary: Returns the full path to the directory containing the application's entry assembly. Will succeed for the main AppDomain of an application started as an .exe; will throw for anything that doesn't have an entry assembly, such as a manually created AppDomain.

member.name: T:RT.Util.ToggleRelativeProblem
member.summary: Details a problem that occurred while using .

member.summary: The base path is not an absolute path.

member.summary: The two paths are both absolute and on different drives, making it impossible to make one of them relative to the other.

member.summary: The base path is not a valid path and/or contains invalid characters.

member.name: F:RT.Util.ToggleRelativeProblem.InvalidToggledPath
member.summary: The toggled path is not a valid path and/or contains invalid characters.

member.name: T:RT.Util.CommandRunner
member.summary: Provides features to execute cmd.exe commands in a hidden window and retrieve their output. This class is geared heavily towards executing console programs, batch files and console scripts, but can also execute built-in commands and non-console programs. Because the command goes through cmd.exe, the PATH, PATHEXT and file associations are all automatically taken care of.

remarks.para: When the command completes, whether by exiting naturally or by being aborted, the changes first. Then the event fires. Finally, the is signalled. By the time the has changed to , it is guaranteed that all the output has been processed and the can be retrieved.
This class is thread-safe: all public members may be used from any thread.

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandRunner.SetCommand(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String})
member.summary: Sets the property by concatenating the command and any arguments while escaping values with spaces. Each value must be a single command / executable / script / argument. Null values are allowed and are skipped as if they weren't present. See Remarks.
member.remarks: Example: SetCommand(new[] { @"C:\Program Files\Foo\Foo.exe", "-f", @"C:\Some Path\file.txt" });

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandRunner.SetCommand(System.String[])
member.summary: Sets the property by concatenating the command and any arguments while escaping values with spaces. Each value must be a single command / executable / script / argument. Null values are allowed and are skipped as if they weren't present. See Remarks.
member.remarks: Example: SetCommand(new[] { @"C:\Program Files\Foo\Foo.exe", "-f", @"C:\Some Path\file.txt" });

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandRunner.Start
member.summary: Starts the command with all the settings as configured.

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandRunner.StartAndWait
member.summary: Starts the command with all the settings as configured. Does not return until the command exits.

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandRunner.ArgsToCommandLine(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String})
member.summary: Given a number of argument strings, constructs a single command line string with all the arguments escaped correctly so that a process using standard Windows API for parsing the command line will receive exactly the strings passed in here. See Remarks.
member.remarks: The string is only valid for passing directly to a process. If the target process is invoked by passing the process name + arguments to cmd.exe then further escaping is required, to counteract cmd.exe's interpretation of additional special characters. See .

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandRunner.EscapeCmdExeMetachars(System.String)
member.summary: Escapes all cmd.exe meta-characters by prefixing them with a ^. See for more information.

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandRunner.Abort
member.summary: Aborts the command by killing the process and all its children, if any. Throws if the command has not been started yet. Does nothing if the command has already ended. See Remarks.
member.remarks: It is theoretically possible that this method will fail to terminate a child, if called at exactly the wrong time while a child process is being spawned. To avoid this possibility, pause the process tree first by calling (but see its remarks too).

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandRunner.Pause(System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan})
member.summary: Pauses the command for the specified duration by suspending every thread in every process in the process tree. Throws if the command hasn't been started or has been aborted. Does nothing if the command has exited. If called when already paused, will make sure the command is paused for at least the specified duration, but will not shorten the resume timer. See Remarks.
member.param: Pause duration. Zero and negative intervals do not pause the command at all. Use TimeSpan.MaxValue or null for an indefinite pause.
member.remarks: It is theoretically possible for this to fail to suspend all threads in all processes, if a new thread is created while the threads are being suspended. The current code does not address this scenario, but this can be fixed, if necessary.

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandRunner.ResumePaused
member.summary: Resumes the command after it has been paused. If the command was paused with a timeout, the timer is cleared. Throws if the command has not been started yet or has been aborted. Does nothing if the command is not paused.

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandRunner.Run(System.String[])
member.summary: Executes the specified command using a fluid syntax. Use method chaining to configure any options, then invoke (or one of its variants) to execute the command. See Remarks.
member.param: The command and its arguments, if any. Each value is automatically escaped as needed. See for further information. See for an alternative way to specify the command.

remarks.para: The default options are as follows: 0 is the only exit code indicating success; print the command output to the console as-is.
Example: CommandRunner.Run(@"C:\Program Files\Foo\Foo.exe", "-f", @"C:\Some Path\file.txt").SuccessExitCodes(0, 1).OutputNothing().Go();

member.name: M:RT.Util.CommandRunner.RunRaw(System.String)
member.summary: Executes the specified command using a fluid syntax. Use method chaining to configure any options, then invoke (or one of its variants) to execute the command. See Remarks.
member.param: The command and its arguments. All arguments must be escaped as appropriate.

remarks.para: The default options are as follows: 0 is the only exit code indicating success; print the command output to the console as-is.
Example: CommandRunner.RunRaw(@"C:\Program Files\Foo\Foo.exe -f ""C:\Some Path\file.txt""").SuccessExitCodes(0, 1).Go();

member.name: E:RT.Util.CommandRunner.CommandEnded
member.summary: Raised once the command ends (that is, exits naturally or is aborted) and all the clean-up has completed. See Remarks.
member.remarks: When this event occurs, the is guaranteed to be in either the or state. The will not have fired yet, and will only fire once this event handler is completed.

member.name: E:RT.Util.CommandRunner.CommandResumed
member.summary: Raised whenever the command execution resumes after it was paused. This includes manual calls to .

member.name: E:RT.Util.CommandRunner.StdoutData
member.summary: Raised whenever the command has produced new output on stdout (but no more often than about once in 50ms).

member.name: E:RT.Util.CommandRunner.StderrData
member.summary: Raised whenever the command has produced new output on stderr (but no more often than about once in 50ms).

member.name: E:RT.Util.CommandRunner.StdoutText
member.summary: Raised whenever the command has produced new text on stdout. For ASCII outputs, this is identical to , however utf8-encoded text is guaranteed to correctly handle the possibility that part of a character's encoding has not been output yet. Other encodings are not supported.

member.name: E:RT.Util.CommandRunner.StderrText
member.summary: Same as but for stderr.

member.name: P:RT.Util.CommandRunner.CaptureEntireStdout
member.summary: Specifies whether the entire stdout output should be captured. This can consume large amounts of memory, and so defaults to false.

member.name: P:RT.Util.CommandRunner.CaptureEntireStderr
member.summary: Specifies whether the entire stderr output should be captured. This can consume large amounts of memory, and so defaults to false.

member.name: P:RT.Util.CommandRunner.EntireStdout
member.summary: Gets the entire stdout output produced by the program. This property can only be accessed once the command has ended (exited or aborted), and only if is true. You may modify the returned array, but subsequent invocations will then return the modified array. The relative interleaving of stdout and stderr is not preserved in this property.

member.name: P:RT.Util.CommandRunner.EntireStderr
member.summary: Gets the entire stderr output produced by the program. This property can only be accessed once the command has ended (exited or aborted), and only if is true. You may modify the returned array, but subsequent invocations will then return the modified array. The relative interleaving of stdout and stderr is not preserved in this property.

member.name: P:RT.Util.CommandRunner.EndedWaitHandle
member.summary: Exposes a waitable flag indicating whether the command has ended, either by exiting naturally or by being aborted. See also Remarks on .
member.remarks: Calling Set or Reset will result in corruption and undefined behaviour. This should be a read-only waitable flag, but there is no built-in class

member.name: P:RT.Util.CommandRunner.State
member.summary: Indicates the current state of the runner. Some properties are only readable and/or writable in specific states. Note that this property is not guaranteed to reflect whether the actual command is running or not, or whether a call to resulted in the command of being terminated; rather, this is the logical state of the itself.

member.name: P:RT.Util.CommandRunner.ExitCode

member.name: P:RT.Util.CommandRunner.Command
member.summary: The command to be executed, as a single string. Any command supported by cmd.exe is permitted. See also , which simplifies running commands with spaces and/or arguments. Once the command has been started, this property becomes read-only and indicates the value in effect at the time of starting. See Remarks.

member.name: P:RT.Util.CommandRunner.WorkingDirectory

member.name: T:RT.Util.RhoML
member.summary: Exposes methods related to the RhoML language. See Remarks.

remarks.para: RhoML is a language which parses into a tree somewhat reminiscent of XML. The document is represented by a root , and consists of a tree of s. Two types of nodes exist: elements, which have a name and may have attributes, and text nodes, which simply contain raw text. Only elements may contain sub-nodes.

Except for the root element, all elements must have a name, which can be an arbitrary string. The root element's name is null. An element may have a default attribute value, as well as any number of additional named attribute/value pairs. The attribute names and values can also be arbitrary strings. A named attribute is not required to have a value.

Syntactically, an element is delimited by an opening and a closing tag. The closing tag is always {} for all elements. The opening tag begins with a {, followed by the element name, the default attribute value (= followed by the value), any number of named attributes (name, =, value, delimited by ,), and ends with a }.
The following is an example of valid RhoML with an explanation of what is represented:
remarks.code: Basic {font=Times New Roman}example{}: element named "font" with the default attribute set. Another {blah,foo=bar,stuff}example{}: element named "blah", no default attribute, two named attributes ("foo" and "stuff"), the first of which has the value "bar" while the second one has no value. Other than the two elements, the rest of this RhoML is literal text.
remarks.para: The element name and attribute names/values can all be specified using either quoted or unquoted syntax. Unquoted syntax is limited in what strings can be expressed, while quoted syntax allows every possible string to be represented:

item.description: Unquoted values always terminate at {, }, =, ,, `, newlines and tabs, and these cannot be escaped. All other characters are allowed and are interpreted literally. Spaces are allowed but leading and trailing spaces will be ignored.

Quoted values begin and end with a `. Actual backticks can be represented by ``. All other characters are interpreted literally inside a quoted value, and there are no special escape sequences for newlines or other non-printing characters.

remarks.para: Whitespace is significant in all contexts, with some exceptions inside the opening tag of an element. Specifically, whitespace is ignored inside the opening tag between all syntactic elements (but not inside names/values), with the sole exception of immediately after {: this character must be followed by a ` (beginning the element name in quoted syntax) or a Unicode letter or digit (beginning the tag name in unquoted syntax). Otherwise the { character is interpreted as a literal opening curly bracket.

Within a run of text, only the { character needs special attention; all other characters are interpreted literally. The { character is also interpreted literally unless followed by a { (in which case the two are interpreted as a single literal curly bracket), } (interpreted as the closing tag), or a `/letter/digit (interpreted as the start of an opening tag).
A more complex example (the entire example is valid RhoML):
remarks.code: This curly bracket { is interpreted literally, as is this } one. This {{ is a single open curly. Here {` is ``{ `}an element{} whose name is " is `{ ", containing a text node with the text "an element". Here's an element with some generous {use = of spaces , you = see}.{}; this represents an element named "use", with a default attribute value "of spaces", and an attribute named "you" with a value "see".

member.name: T:RT.Util.Emailer
member.summary: Implements a simple interface for sending an email that shares a global repository of SMTP settings. This repository is stored using using the name "RT.Emailer". The repository contains a list of SMTP accounts with a unique name. One of the accounts may be designated as the default one if the application doesn't specify any. The "From" address is fixed per account, but the name may be overridden by the application.

Once the above is done, the settings can be saved by calling /, depending on intent. To load, call , making sure that the generic type is the type of your descendant class. For example:
implements an extra method to enable settings to be queued for a save on a separate thread, to reduce the performance impact of less important saves.

member.name: M:RT.Util.SettingsBase.BeforeSave

Note that this may be called on a different thread than the one invoking a Save* operation (but the same as the thread performing the save immediately after this method returns).

member.name: M:RT.Util.SettingsBase.AfterLoad

summary.para: This method is fully compatible with , and will cancel any pending earlier (older) saves.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Serialization.Classify
member.summary: Provides static methods to represent objects of (almost) arbitrary classes in various formats (such as XML or JSON) and to restore such objects again. See the remarks section for features and limitations.

remarks.para: By default, when serializing a custom class, Classify persists the value of all instance fields, including private, inherited and compiler-generated ones. It does not persist static members or the result of property getters. Each field is persisted under a name that is the field’s name minus any leading underscores. Compiler-generated fields for automatically-implemented properties are instead named after the automatically-implemented property’s name minus any leading underscores.
Classify can also generate representations of basic types such as string, int, bool, etc.
Features:

item.description: Classify fully supports all the built-in types which are keywords in C# except object and dynamic. It also supports DateTime and all enum types.
Classify fully supports classes and structs that contain only fields of the above types as well as fields whose type is itself such a class or struct.

Classify has special handling for classes that implement IDictionary<TKey, TValue>, where TValue must be a type also supported by Classify. TKey must be string, an integer type or an enum type. If the field is of a concrete type, that type is maintained, but its extra fields are not persisted. If the field is of the interface type IDictionary<TKey, TValue> itself, the type Dictionary<TKey, TValue> is used to reconstruct the object.

Classify has special handling for classes that implement ICollection<T>, where T must be a type also supported by Classify. If the field is of a concrete type, that type is maintained, but its extra fields are not persisted. If the field is of the interface type ICollection<T> or IList<T> itself, the type List<T> is used to reconstruct the object. If the type also implements IDictionary<TKey, TValue>, the special handling for that takes precedence.
Classify also supports and all the different System.Tuple<...> types.

Classify handles the element type specially. For example, if you are classifying to XML, classifying an object generates the XML directly; if you are classifying to JSON, the same goes for objects, etc.

For classes that don’t implement any of the above-mentioned collection interfaces, Classify supports polymorphism. The actual type of an instance is persisted if it is different from the declared type.
Classify supports auto-implemented properties. It uses the name of the property rather than the hidden auto-generated field, although the field’s value is persisted. All other properties are ignored.

Classify ignores the order of input elements (except when handling collections and dictionaries). For example, XML tags or JSON dictionary keys are mapped to fields by their names; their order is considered immaterial.

Classify silently discards unrecognized XML tags/JSON dictionary keys instead of throwing errors. This is by design because it enables the programmer to remove a field from a class without invalidating objects previously persisted.

Classify silently ignores missing elements. A field whose element is missing retains the value assigned to it by the parameterless constructor. This is by design because it enables the programmer to add a new field to a class (and to specify a default initialization value for it) without invalidating objects previously persisted.

The following custom attributes can be used to alter Classify’s behavior. See the custom attribute class’s documentation for more information: , , , , , , . Any attribute that can be used on a field, can equally well be used on an auto-implemented property, but not on any other properties.
Classify maintains object identity and correctly handles cycles in the object graph. Only strings are exempt from this.
Classify can make use of type substitutions. See for more information.
Classify allows you to pre-/post-process the serialized form and/or the serialized objects. See , , and for more information.

remarks.para: Limitations:

item.description: Classify requires that every type involved have a parameterless constructor, although it need not be public. This parameterless constructor is executed with all its side-effects before each object is reconstructed. An exception is made when a field in an object already has a non-null instance assigned to it by the constructor; in such cases, the object is reused.

If a field is of type ICollection<T>, IList<T>, IDictionary<TKey, TValue>, or any class that implements either of these, polymorphism is not supported, and nor is any information stored in those classes. In particular, this means that the comparer used by a SortedDictionary<TKey, TValue> is not persisted. However, if the containing class’s constructor assigned a SortedDictionary<TKey, TValue> with a comparer, that instance, and hence its comparer, is reused.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyOptions
member.summary: Specifies some options for use by .

member.name: F:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyOptions.BaseDir
member.summary: The base directory from which to construct the paths for additional files whenever a field has an attribute. Inferred automatically from filename if null.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyOptions.EnforceEnums
member.summary: This option is only relevant if the value you are deserializing is an enum value or a collection or dictionary involving enum keys or values. If true, only enum values declared in the enum type are allowed (as if it were a field with ). Enum values inside of objects are not affected by this option (but only by ).

member.name: M:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyOptions.AddTypeOptions(System.Type,RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyTypeOptions)
member.summary: Adds options that are relevant to classifying/declassifying a specific type.
member.param: The type to which these options apply.

Options that apply to the . To enable type substitution, pass an instance of a class that implements . To use pre-/post-processing of the object or its serialized form, pass an instance of a class that implements or .
member.returns: Itself.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyTypeOptions
member.summary: Provides an abstract base type to derive from to specify type-specific options for use in Classify. See remarks for more information.

remarks.para: Derive from this type and implement to enable type substitution during Classify. (This type substitution can be overridden by the presence of a on a field or automatically-implemented property.)
Derive from this type and implement or to pre-/post-process the object or its serialized form before/after Classify. (You can also implement or on the serialized type itself.)
Intended use is to declare a class derived from and pass an instance of it into .

member.name: T:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyFollowIdAttribute
member.summary: If this attribute is used on a field or automatically-implemented property, stores an ID that points to another, separate file which in turn contains the actual object. This is only allowed on fields or automatically-implemented properties of type for some type T. Use to retrieve the object. This retrieval is deferred until first use. Use to retrieve the ID used to reference the object. You can also capture the ID into the type T by using the attribute within that type.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyIgnoreAttribute
member.summary: If this attribute is used on a field or automatically-implemented property, it is ignored by . Data stored in this field or automatically-implemented property is not persisted.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifySubstituteAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value stored in this field or automatically-implemented property should be converted to another type when serializing and back when deserializing. This takes precedence over any type substitution configured in a derived class.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifySubstituteAttribute.#ctor(System.Type)
member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: Specifies a type that implements , where TTrue must be the exact type of the field or automatically-implemented property bearing this attribute.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifySubstituteAttribute.ConverterType
member.summary: Gets the type used to perform the type substitution.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyIgnoreIfDefaultAttribute
member.summary: If this attribute is used on a field or automatically-implemented property, omits its serialization if the value is null, 0, false, etc. If it is used on a type, it applies to all fields and automatically-implemented properties in the type. See also remarks.

item.description: Using this together with will cause the distinction between null and an empty collection to be lost. However, a collection containing only null elements is persisted correctly.

Do not use this custom attribute on a field that has a non-default value set in the containing class’s constructor. Doing so will cause a serialized null/0/false value to revert to that constructor value upon deserialization.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyIgnoreIfEmptyAttribute
member.summary: If this attribute is used on a field or automatically-implemented property, omits its serialization if that serialization would be completely empty. If it is used on a type, it applies to all collection-type fields in the type. See also remarks.
member.remarks: Using this together with will cause the distinction between null and an empty collection to be lost. However, a collection containing only null elements is persisted correctly.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyIgnoreIfAttribute
member.summary: If this attribute is used on a field or automatically-implemented property, omits its serialization if the field’s or property’s value is equal to the specified value. See also remarks.
member.remarks: Using this together with will cause the distinction between the type’s default value and the specified value to be lost.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyIgnoreIfAttribute.#ctor(System.Object)
member.summary: Constructs an instance.
member.param: Specifies the value which causes a field or automatically-implemented property to be ignored.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyIgnoreIfAttribute.Value
member.summary: Retrieves the value which causes a field or automatically-implemented property to be ignored.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyNotNullAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that Classify shall not set this field or automatically-implemented property to null. If the serialized form is null, the field or automatically-implemented property is instead left at the default value assigned by the object’s default constructor.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyEnforceEnumAttribute
member.summary: To be used on a field or automatically-implemented property of an enum type or a collection involving an enum type. Specifies that Classify shall not allow integer values that are not explicitly declared in the relevant enum type. If the serialized form is such an integer, fields or automatically-implemented properties of an enum type are instead left at the default value assigned by the object’s default constructor, while in collections, the relevant element is omitted (changing the size of the collection). If the enum type has the [Flags] attribute, bitwise combinations of the declared values are allowed.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyParentAttribute
member.summary: When reconstructing an interconnected graph of objects using , a field or automatically-implemented property with this attribute receives a reference to an object which refers to this object. This can be used when serializing tree structures to receive a node’s parent. See also remarks.

item.description: If the field or automatically-implemented property is of an incompatible type, a run-time exception occurs.
If there was no parent node, the field or automatically-implemented property is set to null.
When persisting objects, fields and automatically-implemented properties with this attribute are skipped.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Serialization.ClassifyIdAttribute
member.summary: When reconstructing persisted objects using , a field or automatically-implemented property with this attribute receives the ID that was used to refer to the file that stores this object. See for more information. The field or automatically-implemented property must be of type string.

The maximum number of bytes to be read from the underlying stream.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Threading.Periodic
member.summary:
Encapsulates a class performing a certain activity periodically, which can be initiated once and then permanently shut down, but not paused/resumed. The class owns its own separate thread, and manages this thread all by itself. The periodic task is executed on this thread.
The chief differences to are as follows. This class will never issue overlapping activities, even if an activity takes much longer than the interval; the interval is between the end of the previous occurrence of the activity and the start of the next. The activity is executed on a foreground thread (by default), and thus will complete once started, unless a catastrophic abort occurs. When shutting down the activity, it's possible to wait until the last occurrence, if any, has completed fully.
Threading: unsafe (call public methods on the creating thread only) - or is it?

member.name: M:RT.Util.Threading.Periodic.PeriodicActivity
member.summary: Override with a method that performs the desired periodic activity. If this method throws an exception the thread will terminate, but the will occur nevertheless.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Threading.Periodic.LastActivity
member.summary: Override with a method that performs an activity on the same thread as during shutdown, just before signalling that the shutdown is complete. The default implementation of this method does nothing. This method is guaranteed to be called during a shutdown, even if the shutdown is due to an exception propagating outside of .

member.name: M:RT.Util.Threading.Periodic.Start(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Schedules the periodic activity to start occurring. This method may only be called once.
member.param: By default (false) the class will use a foreground thread, preventing application shutdown until the thread has terminated. If true, a background thread will be created instead.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Threading.Periodic.Shutdown(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Causes the periodic activity to stop occurring. If called while the activity is being performed, will wait until the activity has completed before returning. Ensures that is false once this method returns.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Threading.Periodic.FirstInterval
member.summary: Override to indicate how long to wait between the call to and the first occurrence of the periodic activity.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Threading.Periodic.SubsequentInterval
member.summary: Override to indicate how long to wait between second and subsequent occurrences of the periodic activity.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Threading.Periodic.IsRunning
member.summary: Returns false before the first call to and after the first call to ; true between them.

summary.para: Encapsulates a class performing multiple related yet independent tasks on the same thread at a certain minimum interval each. Schedules the activity that is the most late at every opportunity, but will never execute more than one activity at a time (as they all share the same thread).
Threading: unsafe (call public methods on the creating thread only)

member.name: T:RT.Util.Threading.RateLimitedAction
member.summary: Simplifies the task of performing a certain action on an arbitrary thread with a certain minimum interval between two invocations. Only a single thread will execute the task; no threads will block waiting for that.

member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: The minimum interval between two invocations.

member.summary: Checks whether it is time to execute the action. If so, executes it on the calling thread and returns only when the action is complete. If not, returns very quickly without blocking. If another thread is currently executing the action, returns very quickly without blocking.
member.param: The action to execute.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Threading.RateLimitedAction.Postpone
member.summary: Makes it so that the next action will occur no earlier than the . If action is already in progress, it will complete as usual.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Threading.RateLimitedAction.Expire
member.summary: Makes it so that the action will occur as soon as possible - namely, the next time a thread invokes the method.

member.summary: Gets/sets the minimum interval between two invocations.

member.summary: Expected to zero the timer, so that future calls to return a value relative to the last time this method was called.

member.summary: Instantiates the timer. The timer will be zeroed, and it will not be running.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Tmr`1.Zero
member.summary: Resets the timer back to zero.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Tmr`1.StartAndZero
member.summary: Resets the timer and makes sure it's running. The current state of the timer is irrelevant.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Tmr`1.StopAndZero
member.summary: Makes sure the timer is not running and zeroes it. The current state of the timer is irrelevant.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Tmr`1.Pause
member.summary: Pauses the timer without zeroing it. This method may be called while the timer is already paused, but a single call to is always sufficient to resume the timer.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Tmr`1.Continue
member.summary: Makes sure the timer is running without zeroing the time reading. If the reading is non-zero, it will continue growing. This method may be called while the timer is already running.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Tmr`1.Current
member.summary: Gets the current reading of the timer. This value increases between consecutive reads while the timer is running, and remains fixed while it's paused.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Tmr`1.Last
member.summary: Gets the reading the timer had just before the last call to any of the methods of this class related to zeroing, pausing and resuming the timer.

member.summary: Resets the timer and makes sure it's running. The current state of the timer is irrelevant.

member.summary: Makes sure the timer is not running and zeroes it. The current state of the timer is irrelevant.

member.name: M:RT.Util.TmrCycles.Pause
member.summary: Pauses the timer without zeroing it. This method may be called while the timer is already paused, but a single call to is always sufficient to resume the timer.

member.name: M:RT.Util.TmrCycles.Continue
member.summary: Makes sure the timer is running without zeroing the time reading. If the reading is non-zero, it will continue growing. This method may be called while the timer is already running.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Ut.RunPostBuildChecks(System.String,System.Reflection.Assembly[])
member.summary: In DEBUG mode, runs all post-build checks defined in the specified assemblies. This is intended to be run as a post-build event. See remarks for details.

remarks.para: In non-DEBUG mode, does nothing and returns 0.
Intended use is as follows:

description.para: Add the following line to your project's post-build event:
Add the following code at the beginning of your project's Main() method:
If your project entails several assemblies, you can specify additional assemblies in the call to . For example, you could specify typeof(SomeTypeInMyLibrary).Assembly.
Add post-build check methods to any type where they may be relevant. For example, for a command-line program that uses , you might use code similar to the following:

The method is expected to have one parameter of type , a return type of void, and it is expected to be static and non-public. Errors and warnings can be reported by calling methods on said object. Alternatively, throwing an exception will also report an error.

member.param: Specifies the path to the folder containing the C# source files.
Specifies the compiled assemblies from which to run post-build checks.
member.returns: 1 if any errors occurred, otherwise 0.

member.summary: Computes a representation of the differences between and using the specified options.
member.typeparam: The type of items to compare.
member.param: The first sequence of elements. Elements only in this sequence are considered "deleted".
The second sequence of elements. Elements only in this sequence are considered "inserted".
The equality comparer to use to compare items in the two sequences, or null to use the default comparer.

If not null, determines which elements are "hard matches" (true) and which are "soft matches" (false). A "hard match" element is one that can always be matched. A "soft match" element is only matched if it is adjacent to a hard match.

If not null, provides a post-processing step for parts of the diff in between consecutive matches. Without a post-processing step, or when the post-processor returns null, these parts are returned as a sequence of deletes followed by a sequence of inserts.
member.returns: An IEnumerable<Tuple<T, DiffOp>> representing the differences between and . Each element in the returned IEnumerable<Tuple<T, DiffOp>> corresponds either to an element present only in (the element is considered “deleted”), an element present only in (the element is considered “inserted”) or an element present in both.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Ut.InternalErrorPrivate(System.String)
member.summary: Raises an internal error. The reason why this is private is so that only the other InternalError functions can call it. This ensures that the function can always backtrack exactly 2 stack frames to get to the place which invoked InternalError.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Ut.ReduceRequiredSet``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Func{RT.Util.Ut.ReduceRequiredSetState{``0},System.Boolean},System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Given a set of values and a function that returns true when given this set, will efficiently remove items from this set which are not essential for making the function return true. The relative order of items is preserved. This method cannot generally guarantee that the result is optimal, but for some types of functions the result will be guaranteed optimal.
member.typeparam: Type of the values in the set.
member.param: The set of items to reduce.
The function that examines the set. Must always return the same value for the same set.

A value selecting a breadth-first or a depth-first approach. Depth-first is best at quickly locating a single value which will be present in the final required set. Breadth-first is best at quickly placing a lower bound on the total number of individual items in the required set.

When the function is particularly slow, you might want to set this to true to disable calls which are not required to reduce the set and are only there to ensure that the function behaves consistently.
member.returns: A hopefully smaller set of values that still causes the function to return true.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Ut.RunMain(System.Action,System.Action{System.Exception},System.Action{System.Exception})
member.summary: Execute the core of the application. In debug mode, exceptions are passed through untouched. In release mode, all exceptions are caught, including those on other threads, and passed on to the specified handlers. Also, the main thread is given the name "Main".
member.param: A method which executes the core of the application.
Method called in case the main method throws an unhandled exception.
Method called in case a thread other than the one executing the main method throws an unhandled exception. If null, will be called instead.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Ut.RunMain(System.Func{System.Int32},System.Func{System.Exception,System.Int32},System.Action{System.Exception})
member.summary: Execute the core of the application. In debug mode, exceptions are passed through untouched. In release mode, all exceptions are caught, including those on other threads, and passed on to the specified handlers. Also, the main thread is given the name "Main".
member.param: A method which executes the core of the application.
Method called in case the main method throws an unhandled exception. The return value is what this method will return.
Method called in case a thread other than the one executing the main method throws an unhandled exception. If null, will be called instead, and its return value will be ignored.

member.summary: Encapsulates the state of the algorithm and exposes statistics about it.

member.summary: Internal; do not use.

member.summary: Internal; do not use.

member.summary: Internal; do not use.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Ut.ReduceRequiredSetState`1.DefinitelyRequired
member.summary: Enumerates every item that is known to be in the final required set. "Definitely" doesn't mean that there exists no subset resulting in "true" without these members. Rather, it means that the algorithm will definitely return these values, and maybe some others too.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Ut.ReduceRequiredSetState`1.PartitionsCount
member.summary: Gets the current number of partitions containing uncertain items. The more of these, the slower the algorithm will converge from here onwards.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Ut.ReduceRequiredSetState`1.SmallestPartitionSize
member.summary: Gets the number of items in the smallest partition. This is the value that is halved upon a successful depth-first iteration.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Ut.ReduceRequiredSetState`1.LargestPartitionSize
member.summary: Gets the number of items in the largest partition. This is the value that is halved upon a successful breadth-first iteration.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Ut.ReduceRequiredSetState`1.ItemsRemaining
member.summary: Gets the total number of items about which the algorithm is currently undecided.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Ut.ReduceRequiredSetState`1.SetToTest
member.summary: Gets the set of items for which the function should be evaluated in the current step.

member.name: T:RT.Util.SettingsThreadedBase
member.summary: Like , but implements an additional save method.

member.name: M:RT.Util.SettingsThreadedBase.CloneForSaveThreaded
member.summary: Must return a deep clone of this class. This will be used to create a snapshot of the settings at the time when is called.

summary.para: Saves the settings. Intended for frequent use at any point where it would make sense to commit settings, but would not make sense to bug the user about any failures. This method is like , except that the actual save occurs slightly later on a separate thread. The method returns as soon as returns.
Note that this method is NOT guaranteed to save settings, but it usually will. Make sure you call when you want to guarantee a save, especially just before the program terminates.

member.name: T:RT.Util.SettingsKind
member.summary: Determines what the settings in the settings file are logically "attached" to.

member.name: F:RT.Util.SettingsKind.MachineSpecific
member.summary: These settings are specific to a particular computer. In normal mode: shared among all user accounts, and do not roam. In portable mode: separate settings stored for every machine name; user account doesn't matter.

member.name: F:RT.Util.SettingsKind.UserSpecific
F:RT.Util.SettingsKind.UserAndMachineSpecific
member.summary: These settings are specific to a particular combination of user and machine. In normal mode: separate settings for each user account on each machine; will not roam. In portable mode: separate settings stored for every machine name; user account doesn't matter.

member.name: F:RT.Util.SettingsKind.Global
member.summary: These settings are intended to be global, with constraints imposed by reality. In normal mode: shared among all user accounts, and do not roam. In portable mode: always shared; user account and machine name do not matter.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Streams.ArithmeticCodingReader
member.summary: Provides a read-only stream that can decompress data that was compressed using Arithmetic Coding.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Streams.ArithmeticCodingReader.END_OF_STREAM
member.summary: Encapsulates a symbol that represents the end of the stream. All other symbols are byte values.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Streams.ArithmeticCodingReader.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,System.UInt64[])
member.summary: Initialises an instance given a base stream and a set of byte probabilities.
member.param: The base stream to which the compressed data will be written.

The probability of each byte occurring. Can be null, in which case all bytes are assumed to have the same probability. The set of probabilities must be exactly the same as the one used when the data was written using .

member.name: M:RT.Util.Streams.ArithmeticCodingReader.ReadSymbol
member.summary: Reads a single symbol. Use this if you are not using bytes as your symbol alphabet.
member.returns: Symbol read.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Streams.ArithmeticCodingWriter
member.summary: Provides a write-only stream that can compress data using Arithmetic Coding.

member.name: F:RT.Util.Streams.ArithmeticCodingWriter.END_OF_STREAM
member.summary: Encapsulates a symbol that represents the end of the stream. All other symbols are byte values.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Streams.ArithmeticCodingWriter.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,System.UInt64[])
member.summary: Initialises an instance given a base stream and a set of byte probabilities.
member.param: The base stream to which the compressed data will be written.

The probability of each byte occurring. Can be null, in which case all bytes are assumed to have the same probability. When reading the data back using an , the set of probabilities must be exactly the same.
member.remarks: The compressed data will not be complete until the stream is closed using .

member.name: M:RT.Util.Streams.ArithmeticCodingWriter.WriteSymbol(System.Int32)
member.summary: Writes a single symbol. Use this if you are not using bytes as your symbol alphabet.
member.param: Symbol to write. Must be an integer between 0 and the length of the probabilities array passed in the constructor.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Streams.ArithmeticCodingWriter.Close(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Closes the stream, optionally writing an end-of-stream symbol first. The end-of-stream symbol has the numeric value 257, which is useful only if you have 256 symbols or fewer. If you intend to use a larger symbol alphabet, write your own end-of-stream symbol and then invoke Close(false).
member.param: Determines whether to write the end-of-stream symbol or not.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Streams.ArithmeticCodingWriter.TweakProbabilities(System.UInt64[])
member.summary: Changes the probabilities of the symbols. This can be used at any point in the middle of encoding, as long as the same change is made at the same time when decoding using .

member.name: T:RT.Util.Streams.CRC32Stream
member.summary: Calculates CRC32 checksum of all values that are read/written via this stream. Seeking is ignored. All the bytes seeked over will be ignored.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Streams.CRC32Stream.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads a chunk of bytes from the underlying stream. Updates the CRC with the data read.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Streams.CRC32Stream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Writes a chunk of bytes to the underlying stream. Updates the CRC with the data written.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Streams.CRC32Stream.BaseStream
member.summary: The underlying stream to/from which writing/reading is performed.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Streams.CRC32Stream.CRC
member.summary: Gets the current value of the CRC32 for all the bytes that passed through this stream.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Streams.DynamicContentStream
member.summary: Provides a read-only stream that can “read from” an IEnumerable<string> or IEnumerable<byte[]>. In particular, an intended application is to “read from” a method that uses yield return to return strings or data as execution proceeds. This enables generation of, for example, HTML for dynamic web pages.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Xml.XmlClassify
member.summary: This class is obsolete. Use instead. — Provides static methods to save objects of (almost) arbitrary classes into XML files and load them again. See the remarks section for features and limitations.

remarks.para: This class is obsolete. New code should use instead.

By default, XmlClassify persists the value of all instance fields, including private, inherited and compiler-generated ones. It does not persist static members or the result of property getters. Each field is persisted in an XML tag whose name is the field’s name minus any leading underscores. Compiler-generated fields for automatically-implemented properties are instead persisted in an XML tag whose name is the automatically-implemented property’s name minus any leading underscores.
Features:

item.description: XmlClassify fully supports all the built-in types which are keywords in C# except ‘object’ and ‘dynamic’. It also supports DateTime.
XmlClassify fully supports classes and structs that contain only fields of the above types as well as fields whose type is itself such a class or struct.

XmlClassify has special handling for classes that implement IDictionary<K, V>, where V must be a type also supported by XmlClassify. K must be string, an integer type, or an enum type. If the field is of a concrete type, that type is maintained. If the field is of the interface type IDictionary<K, V> itself, the type Dictionary<K, V> is used to reconstruct the object.

XmlClassify has special handling for classes that implement ICollection<T>, where T must be a type also supported by XmlClassify. If the field is of a concrete type, that type is maintained. If the field is of the interface type ICollection<T> itself, the type List<T> is used to reconstruct the object. If the type also implements IDictionary<K, V>, the special handling for that takes precedence.
XmlClassify handles the type by persisting the XML directly.
XmlClassify also supports and all the different Tuple types.
For classes that don’t implement any of the above-mentioned interfaces, XmlClassify supports polymorphism. The actual type of an instance is persisted if it is different from the declared type.

XmlClassify supports auto-implemented properties. The XML tag’s name is the name of the property rather than the hidden auto-generated field, although the field’s value is persisted. All other properties are ignored.
XmlClassify ignores the order of XML tags (except when handling collections and dictionaries). It uses tag names to identify which tag belongs to which field.

XmlClassify silently discards unrecognised XML tags instead of throwing errors. This is by design because it enables the programmer to remove a field from a class without invalidating previously-saved XML files.

XmlClassify silently ignores missing XML tags. A field whose XML tag is missing retains the value assigned to it by the parameterless constructor. This is by design because it enables the programmer to add a new field to a class (and to specify a default initialisation value for it) without invalidating previously-saved XML files.

The following custom attributes can be used to alter XmlClassify’s behaviour. See the custom attribute class’s documentation for more information: , , , , , , . Any attribute that can be used on a field, can equally well be used on an auto-implemented property, but not on any other properties.
XmlClassify maintains object identity and correctly handles cycles in the object graph (by using XML attributes to refer to earlier tags).
XmlClassify can make use of type substitutions. See for more information.
XmlClassify allows you to pre-/post-process the objects serialised by it. See for more information.
XmlClassify allows you to pre-/post-process the XML generated by it. See for more information.

remarks.para: Limitations:

item.description: XmlClassify requires that every type involved have a parameterless constructor, although it need not be public. This parameterless constructor is executed with all its side-effects before each object is reconstructed.

If a field is of type ICollection<T>, IList<T>, IDictionary<K, V>, or any class that implements either of these, polymorphism is not supported, and nor is any information stored in those classes. In particular, this means that the comparer used by a SortedDictionary<K, V> is not persisted. A comparer assigned by the class’s parameterless constructor is also not used.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Xml.IXmlClassifyProcess

member.summary: Pre-processes this object before turns it into XML. This method is automatically invoked by and should not be called directly.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Xml.IXmlClassifyProcess.AfterXmlDeclassify
member.summary: Post-processes this object after has restored it from XML. This method is automatically invoked by and should not be called directly.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Xml.IXmlClassifyProcess2
member.summary: Contains methods to process an object and/or the associated XML before or after (de)serializes it. To have effect, this interface must be implemented by the object being serialised.

member.param: The (initially empty) XML element which will be populated once this class returns. Any changes made to it by the method may be either trampled upon the method's return, or conflict with changes and cause it to throw an exception.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Xml.IXmlClassifyProcess2.AfterXmlClassify(System.Xml.Linq.XElement)
member.summary: Post-processes the XML produced by for this object. This method is automatically invoked by and should not be called directly.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Xml.IXmlClassifyProcess2.BeforeXmlDeclassify(System.Xml.Linq.XElement)

member.param: The XML element from which this object is about to be restored. All changes made to it will affect how the object is restored from XML.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Xml.IXmlClassifyProcess2.AfterXmlDeclassify(System.Xml.Linq.XElement)
member.summary: Post-processes this object after has restored it from XML. This method is automatically invoked by and should not be called directly.
member.param: The XML element from which this object was restored. Changes made to this XML will have no effect as the XML is discarded afterwards.

Options that apply to the . To enable type substitution, pass an instance of a class that implements . To use XML pre-/post-processing, pass an instance of a class that implements .

member.summary: Provides an abstract base type to derive from to specify type-specific options for use in XmlClassify. See remarks for more information.

Derive from this type and implement to pre-/post-process the XML before/after XmlClassify.
Instances of derived classes are passed into .

member.name: T:RT.Util.Xml.XmlFollowIdAttribute
member.summary: If this attribute is used on a field or automatically-implemented property, stores an ID in the corresponding XML tag that points to another, separate XML file which in turn contains the actual object for this field or automatically-implemented property. This is only allowed on fields or automatically-implemented properties of type for some type T. Use to retrieve the object. This retrieval is deferred until first use. Use to retrieve the ID used to reference the object. You can also capture the ID into the class or struct T by using the attribute within that class or struct.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Xml.XmlIgnoreAttribute
member.summary: If this attribute is used on a field or automatically-implemented property, it is ignored by . Data stored in this field or automatically-implemented property is not persisted.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Xml.XmlIgnoreIfDefaultAttribute
member.summary: If this attribute is used on a field or automatically-implemented property, does not generate a tag if the value is null, 0, false, etc. If it is used on a class or struct, it applies to all fields and automatically-implemented properties in the class or struct. Notice that using this together with will cause the distinction between null and an empty element to be lost. However, a collection containing only null elements is persisted correctly.
member.remarks: Warning: Do not use this custom attribute on a field that has a non-default value set in the containing class’s constructor. Doing so will cause a serialised “null” to revert to that constructor value upon deserliasation.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Xml.XmlIgnoreIfEmptyAttribute
member.summary: If this attribute is used on a field or automatically-implemented property, does not generate a tag if that tag would be completely empty (no attributes or subelements). If it is used on a class or struct, it applies to all collection-type fields in the class or struct. Notice that using this together with will cause the distinction between null and an empty element to be lost. However, a collection containing only null elements is persisted correctly.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Xml.XmlIgnoreIfAttribute
member.summary: If this attribute is used on a field or automatically-implemented property, does not generate a tag if the field’s or property’s value is equal to the specified value. Notice that using this together with will cause the distinction between the type’s default value and the specified value to be lost.

member.name: M:RT.Util.Xml.XmlIgnoreIfAttribute.#ctor(System.Object)
member.summary: Constructs an instance.
member.param: Specifies the value which causes a field or automatically-implemented property to be ignored.

member.name: P:RT.Util.Xml.XmlIgnoreIfAttribute.Value
member.summary: Retrieves the value which causes a field or automatically-implemented property to be ignored.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Xml.XmlParentAttribute
member.summary: When reconstructing persisted objects using , a field or automatically-implemented property with this attribute receives a reference to the object which was its parent node in the XML tree. If the field or automatically-implemented property is of an incompatible type, a run-time exception occurs. If there was no parent node, the field or automatically-implemented property is set to null. When persisting objects, fields and automatically-implemented properties with this attribute are skipped.

member.name: T:RT.Util.Xml.XmlIdAttribute
member.summary: When reconstructing persisted objects using , a field or automatically-implemented property with this attribute receives the ID that was used to refer to the XML file that stores this object. See for more information. The field or automatically-implemented property must be of type string.
